<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Indicate by check mark whether any of the registrants is a shell company (as defined in Rule 12b-2 of the Exchange Act). Yes&nbsp;</font><font color=#000000><font face="Wingdings 2">&#163;</font></font><font color=#000000>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;No&nbsp;</font><font color=#000000><font face="Wingdings 2">&#083;</font></font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of April&nbsp;30, 2006, Public Service Enterprise Group Incorporated had outstanding 251,469,431 shares of its sole class of Common Stock, without par value.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of April&nbsp;30, 2006, Public Service Electric and Gas Company had issued and outstanding&nbsp;132,450,344 shares of Common Stock, without nominal or par value, all of which were privately held, beneficially and of record by Public Service Enterprise Group Incorporated.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG Power&nbsp;LLC and PSEG Energy Holdings&nbsp;L.L.C. are wholly owned subsidiaries of Public Service Enterprise Group Incorporated and meet the conditions set forth in General Instruction&nbsp;H(1) (a) and (b) of Form&nbsp;10-Q and are filing their respective Quarterly Reports on Form&nbsp;10-Q with the reduced disclosure format authorized by General Instruction&nbsp;H.</font></p>

<p align=center><b><font color=#000000><a name='Forward'>FORWARD-LOOKING STATEMENTS</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Certain of the matters discussed in this report constitute &ldquo;forward-looking statements&rdquo; within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Such forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties, which could cause actual results to differ materially from those anticipated. Such statements are based on management&#39;s beliefs as well as assumptions made by and information currently available to management. When used herein, the words &ldquo;anticipate,&rdquo; &ldquo;intend,&rdquo; &ldquo;estimate,&rdquo; &ldquo;believe,&rdquo; &ldquo;expect,&rdquo; &ldquo;plan,&rdquo; &ldquo;hypothetical,&rdquo; &ldquo;potential,&rdquo; &ldquo;forecast,&rdquo; &ldquo;project,&rdquo; variations of such words and similar expressions are intended to identify forward-looking statements. Public
Service Enterprise Group Incorporated (PSEG), Public Service Electric and Gas Company (PSE&amp;G), PSEG Power&nbsp;LLC (Power) and PSEG Energy Holdings&nbsp;L.L.C. (Energy Holdings) undertake no obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. The following review should not be construed as a complete list of factors that could affect forward-looking statements. In addition to any assumptions and other factors referred to specifically in connection with such forward-looking statements discussed above, factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those contemplated in any forward-looking statements include, among others, the following:</font></p>

Each of PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings expressly disclaims any obligation or undertaking to release publicly any updates or revisions to these forward-looking statements to reflect events or circumstances that occur or arise or are anticipated to occur
or arise after the date hereof. In making any investment decision regarding PSEG&#39;s, PSE&amp;G&#39;s, Power&#39;s and Energy Holdings&#39; securities, PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings are not making, and you should not infer, any representation about the likely existence of any particular future set of facts or circumstances. The forward-looking statements contained in this report are intended to qualify for the safe harbor provisions of Section&nbsp;27A of the Securities Act of 1933, as amended, and Section&nbsp;21E of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended.</font></p>

<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000><a name='Notes'>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS</a><br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>This combined Form&nbsp;10-Q is separately filed by Public Service Enterprise Group Incorporated (PSEG), Public Service Electric and Gas Company (PSE&amp;G), PSEG Power&nbsp;LLC (Power) and PSEG Energy Holdings&nbsp;L.L.C. (Energy Holdings). Information contained herein relating to any individual company is filed by such company on its own behalf. PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings each make representations only as to itself and make no representations as to any other company.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='Note1'>Note&nbsp;1. Organization and Basis of Presentation</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Organization</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG has four principal direct wholly owned subsidiaries: PSE&amp;G, Power, Energy Holdings and PSEG Services Corporation (Services).</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As previously disclosed, on December&nbsp;20, 2004, PSEG entered into an agreement and plan of merger (Merger Agreement) with Exelon Corporation (Exelon), a public utility holding company headquartered in Chicago, Illinois, whereby PSEG will be merged with and into Exelon (Merger). Under the Merger Agreement, each share of PSEG Common Stock will be converted into 1.225 shares of Exelon Common Stock.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The Merger Agreement has been unanimously approved by both companies&#39; Boards of Directors. On July&nbsp;19, 2005, shareholders of PSEG voted to approve the Merger and on July&nbsp;22, 2005, shareholders of Exelon voted to approve the issuance of common shares to PSEG shareholders to effect the Merger.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The Merger Agreement provides that if the Merger is not consummated by June&nbsp;20, 2006, either party may terminate the Merger Agreement.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G is an operating public utility engaged principally in the transmission of electric energy and distribution of electric energy and natural gas in certain areas of New Jersey. PSE&amp;G is subject to regulation by the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities (BPU) and the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC).</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G also owns&nbsp;PSE&amp;G Transition Funding&nbsp;LLC (Transition Funding) and&nbsp;PSE&amp;G Transition Funding&nbsp;II LLC (Transition Funding&nbsp;II), bankruptcy-remote entities that purchased certain transition property from&nbsp;PSE&amp;G and issued transition bonds secured by such property. The transition property consists principally of the right to receive electricity consumption-based per kilowatt-hour (kWh) charges from&nbsp;PSE&amp;G electric distribution customers, which represents the irrevocable right to receive amounts sufficient to recover certain of&nbsp;PSE&amp;G&#39;s transition costs related to deregulation, as approved by the&nbsp;BPU.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power is a multi-regional, wholesale energy supply company that integrates its generating asset operations and gas supply commitments with its wholesale energy, fuel supply, energy trading and marketing and risk management function through three principal direct wholly owned subsidiaries: PSEG Nuclear&nbsp;LLC (Nuclear), PSEG Fossil&nbsp;LLC (Fossil) and PSEG Energy Resources &amp; Trade&nbsp;LLC (ER&amp;T). Nuclear and Fossil own and operate generation and generation-related facilities. ER&amp;T is responsible for the day-to-day management of Power&#39;s portfolio. Fossil, Nuclear and&nbsp;ER&amp;T are subject to regulation by FERC and Nuclear is also subject to regulation by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC).</font></p>
<p align=center>16</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Energy Holdings has two principal direct wholly owned subsidiaries: PSEG Global&nbsp;L.L.C. (Global), which owns and operates international and domestic projects engaged in the generation and distribution of energy, including power production facilities and electric distribution companies, and PSEG Resources&nbsp;L.L.C. (Resources), which has invested primarily in energy-related leveraged leases. Energy Holdings also owns Enterprise Group Development Corporation (EGDC), a commercial real estate property management business.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Services</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Services provides management and administrative services to PSEG and its subsidiaries. These include accounting, legal, communications, human resources, information technology, treasury and financial services, investor relations, stockholder services, real estate, environmental, health and safety, insurance, risk management, tax, library, records and information services, security, corporate secretarial and certain planning, budgeting and forecasting services. Services charges PSEG and its subsidiaries for the cost of work performed and services provided pursuant to the terms and conditions of intercompany service agreements.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Basis of Presentation</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The respective financial statements included herein have been prepared pursuant to the rules and regulations of the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) for Quarterly Reports on Form&nbsp;10-Q. Certain information and note disclosures normally included in financial statements prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States (GAAP) have been condensed or omitted pursuant to such rules and regulations. These Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements and Notes to Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements (Notes) should be read in conjunction with, and update and supplement matters discussed in PSEG&#39;s, PSE&amp;G&#39;s, Power&#39;s and Energy Holdings&#39; respective Annual Reports on Form&nbsp;10-K for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The unaudited condensed consolidated financial information furnished herein reflects all adjustments which are, in the opinion of management, necessary to fairly state the results for the interim periods presented. All such adjustments are of a normal recurring nature. The year-end Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheets were derived from the audited Consolidated Financial Statements included in the Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005. Certain reclassifications of prior period data have been made to conform with the current presentation.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Pension and Other Postretirement Benefits (OPEB)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG sponsors several qualified and nonqualified pension plans and OPEB plans covering PSEG&#39;s and its participating affiliates&#39; current and former employees who meet certain eligibility criteria. The following table provides the components of net periodic benefit costs relating to all qualified and nonqualified pension and OPEB plans on an aggregate basis. OPEB costs are presented net of the</font></p>
<p align=center>17</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>

<p align=left><font color=#000000>federal subsidy expected for prescription drugs under the Medicare Prescription Drug Improvement and Modernization Act of 2003.</font></p>

<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a Name='Note2'>Note&nbsp;2. Recent Accounting Standards</font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>The following accounting standard was issued, but has not yet been adopted by PSEG as of March&nbsp;31, 2006.</font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Emerging Issues Task Force (EITF) Issue&nbsp;No. 04-13, &ldquo;Accounting for Purchases and Sales of Inventory with the Same Counterparty&rdquo; (EITF&nbsp;04-13)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>EITF&nbsp;04-13 concludes that inventory purchases and sales transactions with the same counterparty that are entered into in contemplation of one another should be combined and treated as nonmonetary exchanges involving inventory. The consensus includes indicators that should be considered in determining whether transactions were entered into in contemplation of one another. The EITF also concludes that exchanges of finished goods for raw materials or work-in-process within the same line of business should be recognized at fair value if the transaction has commercial substance and fair value is determinable within reasonable limits. All other inventory exchanges should be recognized at carrying value. The provisions of EITF&nbsp;04-13 are effective for new inventory arrangements entered into, or</font></p>
<p align=center>18</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>modifications or renewals of existing inventory arrangements occurring in financial periods beginning after March&nbsp;15, 2006. PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings do not believe that adoption of EITF&nbsp;04-13 will have a material effect on their respective financial statements.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>The following accounting standards have been proposed by the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB).</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In July 2005, the FASB issued proposed guidance concerning the accounting for uncertain tax positions and the accounting for a change in the timing of cash flows relating to income taxes generated by leveraged lease transactions.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The proposal concerning uncertain tax positions would require that an uncertain tax position meet a more likely-than-not recognition threshold based on the merits of the position in order for the benefit to be recognized in the financial statements. The proposal also addresses the accrual of interest and penalties related to tax uncertainties and the classification of liabilities on the balance sheet. If implemented in its present form, PSEG and Energy Holdings do not believe the impact of this proposal would be material.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The proposal concerning leveraged leases would require a lessor to perform a recalculation of leveraged lease income when there is a change in the timing of the realization of tax benefits generated by the lease. If implemented in its present form, the proposal could have an impact on earnings of PSEG and Energy Holdings, which could be material.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On March&nbsp;31, 2006, the FASB issued an exposure draft that would require recognition of the overfunded or underfunded positions of defined benefit pension and OPEB plans on the balance sheet. For an underfunded plan, the incremental liability to be recorded would be equal to the difference between the projected benefit obligation and the fair value of plan assets. Statement of Financial Accounting Standard (SFAS) No. 87, &ldquo;Employers&#39; Accounting for Pensions&rdquo; (SFAS&nbsp;87) and SFAS&nbsp;No. 106, &ldquo;Employers&#39; Accounting for Postretirement Benefits Other Than Pensions&rdquo; (SFAS&nbsp;106) allow for deferred recognition of this liability through amortization of this difference over time. Under this exposure draft, actuarial gains and losses and prior service costs and credits that arise during
the period but, pursuant to SFAS&nbsp;87 and SFAS&nbsp;106 are not yet recognized as components of net periodic benefit cost, would be recognized as a component of Other Comprehensive Income, net of tax. For&nbsp;PSE&amp;G, management believes the amounts not yet recognized would be recorded as a Regulatory Asset because the amortization of these costs is reflected in current rates. This would represent more than&nbsp;50% of PSEG&#39;s unrecognized pension and OPEB costs. Such amounts would be adjusted as they are subsequently amortized as a component of net periodic benefit cost. The exposure draft also would require an adjustment to the beginning balance of retained earnings, net of tax, for any transition obligation remaining from the initial application of SFAS&nbsp;87 and&nbsp;106. Such amounts would then not subsequently be amortized as a component of net periodic benefit cost.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings are currently evaluating the potential impact on their respective financial statements, which could be material, if the exposure draft is adopted as proposed.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>The following new accounting standards were adopted by PSEG during the first quarter of 2006.</font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>SFAS&nbsp;No. 123R, &ldquo;Share-Based Payment, revised 2004&rdquo; (SFAS 123R)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Effective January&nbsp;1, 2006, PSEG adopted SFAS&nbsp;No. 123R, which replaces SFAS&nbsp;123, &ldquo;Accounting for Stock-Based Compensation,&rdquo; and supersedes Accounting Principles Board (APB) Opinion&nbsp;No. 25, &ldquo;</font></p>
<p align=center>19</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>Accounting&nbsp;for Stock Issued to Employees&rdquo; (APB&nbsp;25). SFAS 123R focuses primarily on accounting for share-based awards to employees in exchange for services, and it requires entities to recognize compensation expense for these awards. The cost for equity-based awards is expensed based on their grant date fair value, and liability awards are expensed based on their fair value, which is re-measured each reporting period. The pro forma disclosure previously permitted under SFAS&nbsp;123 is no longer an alternative to financial statement recognition.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Prior to January&nbsp;1, 2006, PSEG accounted for stock-based awards under the intrinsic value method of&nbsp;APB 25. In accordance with&nbsp;APB 25, PSEG did not record compensation expense related to its stock option grants because the strike price was equal to the fair value of the underlying stock on the grant date; however, it did record compensation expense over the requisite service period for restricted stock grants and performance unit awards.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>SFAS 123R is applicable to all of PSEG&#39;s outstanding unvested share-based payment awards as of January&nbsp;1, 2006 and all prospective awards using the modified prospective method. Accordingly, the financial results for prior periods were not retroactively adjusted to reflect the effects of SFAS 123R. The compensation expense recorded as a result of adopting SFAS 123R was not material. For additional information, see Note&nbsp;12. Stock-Based Compensation.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>SFAS&nbsp;No. 151, &ldquo;Inventory Costs&rdquo; (SFAS&nbsp;151)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In November 2004, the FASB issued SFAS&nbsp;151, which clarifies the accounting for abnormal amounts of idle facility expense, freight, handling costs and wasted material. This statement requires that abnormal amounts of idle facility expense, freight, handling costs and spoilage be recognized as current-period charges. In addition, this statement requires that allocation of fixed production overheads to the costs of conversion be based on the normal capacity of the production facilities. SFAS&nbsp;151 was effective for inventory costs incurred during fiscal years beginning after June&nbsp;15, 2005. The adoption of SFAS&nbsp;151 did not have a material impact on the respective financial statements of PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>FASB Staff Position (FSP) 115-1 and&nbsp;124-1, &ldquo;The Meaning of Other-Than-Temporary Impairment and its Application to Certain Investments&rdquo; (FSP&nbsp;115-1 and&nbsp;124-1)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>This&nbsp;FSP addresses the determination as to when an investment is considered impaired, whether that impairment is other than temporary, and the measurement of the impairment loss. It also requires certain disclosures about unrealized losses that have not been recognized as other-than-temporary impairments. This guidance applies to equity securities that have a readily determinable fair value and all debt securities. It does not apply to investments accounted for under the equity method. An investment is impaired if its fair value is less than its cost, as assessed at the individual security level. When an investment is impaired, the investor is required to evaluate whether the impairment is other-than-temporary. If other-than-temporary, the unrealized loss must be recognized. For all investments in an unrealized loss
position for which other-than-temporary impairments have not been recognized, the investor should disclose by category of investment the amount of unrealized losses and the fair value of investments with unrealized losses and related narrative disclosures. FSP&nbsp;115-1 and&nbsp;124-1 was effective for reporting periods beginning after December&nbsp;15, 2005. The adoption of this&nbsp;FSP did not have a material effect on PSEG&#39;s, PSE&amp;G&#39;s, Power&#39;s or Energy Holdings&#39; respective financial statements.</font></p>
<p align=center>20</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='Note3'>Note&nbsp;3. Discontinued Operations and Dispositions</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Discontinued Operations</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Waterford Generation Facility (Waterford)</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In September 2005, Power completed the sale of its electric generation facility located in Waterford, Ohio to a subsidiary of American Electric Power Company, Inc.</font></p>

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Elektrocieplownia Chorzow Elcho&nbsp;Sp. Z o.o. (Elcho) and Elektrownia Skawina&nbsp;SA (Skawina)</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On January&nbsp;31, 2006, Global entered into an agreement with&nbsp;CEZ a.s. to sell its interest in two coal-fired plants in Poland, Elcho and Skawina, consistent with its strategy of monetizing assets on an opportunistic basis. The sale is expected to close in the second quarter of 2006 and is expected to yield cash proceeds in excess of $300 million after taxes and transaction costs, which is in excess of the book value of the facilities as of March&nbsp;31, 2006. The agreement is subject to customary conditions, including government consents. The 2005 results for Global&#39;s assets in Poland have been reclassified to Discontinued Operations to reflect Energy Holdings&#39; intention to sell these facilities.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Elcho&#39;s and Skawina&#39;s operating results for the quarters ended March&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005 are summarized below:</font></p>

<p align=center>21</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Elcho&#39;s and Skawina&#39;s total non-recourse debt amounted to $288 million and $23 million as of March&nbsp;31, 2006, respectively, and $287 million and $26 million as of December&nbsp;31, 2005, respectively.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Dispositions</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Solar Electric Generating Systems (SEGS) Projects</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In January 2005, Resources and Global sold their minority limited partner interests in three SEGS projects for proceeds of approximately $7 million, resulting in an after-tax gain of $4 million.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Dhofar Power Company&nbsp;S.A.O.C. (Dhofar Power)</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In April 2005, Global sold a&nbsp;35% interest in Dhofar Power through a public offering on the Omani stock exchange as required under the Concession Agreement, reducing Global&#39;s ownership in Dhofar Power from&nbsp;81% to&nbsp;46%. Net proceeds from the sale approximated $25 million, resulting in an after-tax gain of approximately $1 million. As a result, Global&#39;s investment in Dhofar Power has been accounted for under the equity method following the sale.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Meiya Power Company Limited (MPC)</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In January and April 2005, Global received payments of approximately $38 million and $99 million, respectively, representing the full payment of the receivable relating to the sale of its&nbsp;50% equity interest in&nbsp;MPC in December 2004.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Resources</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In January 2005, a&nbsp;KKR Fund, in which Resources had invested, sold its investment in KinderCare Learning Centers, Inc. and Resources received proceeds of approximately $17 million, resulting in an after-tax gain of approximately $1 million.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='Note4'>Note&nbsp;4. Earnings Per Share (EPS)</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Diluted&nbsp;EPS is calculated by dividing Net Income by the weighted average number of shares of common stock outstanding, including shares issuable upon exercise of stock options outstanding under PSEG&#39;s stock option plans, upon payment of performance units and upon conversion of Participating Units. The following table shows the effect of these stock options, performance units and Participating Units on the weighted average number of shares outstanding used in calculating diluted EPS:</font></p>
<p align=center>22</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>

(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Dividend payments on common stock for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006 were $0.57 per share and totaled approximately $143 million. Dividend payments on common stock for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 were $0.56 per share and totaled approximately $134 million.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='Note5'>Note&nbsp;5. Commitments and Contingent Liabilities</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Guaranteed Obligations</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power has unconditionally guaranteed payments by its subsidiary, ER&amp;T, in certain commodity-related transactions in the ordinary course of business. These payment guarantees were provided to counterparties in order to obtain credit under physical and financial agreements for gas, pipeline capacity, transportation, oil, electricity and related commodities and services. These Power payment guarantees support the current exposure, interest and other costs on sums due and payable by&nbsp;ER&amp;T under these agreements. Guarantees offered for trading and marketing cover lines of credit between entities and are often reciprocal in nature. The exposure between counterparties can move in either direction. The face value of the guarantees outstanding as of March&nbsp;31, 2006 and December&nbsp;31, 2005 was approximately $1.6
billion. In order for Power to incur a liability for the face value of the outstanding guarantees, ER&amp;T would have to fully utilize the credit granted to it by every counterparty to whom Power has provided a guarantee and all of&nbsp;ER&amp;T&#39;s contracts would have to be &ldquo;out-of-the-money&rdquo; (if the contracts are terminated, Power would owe money to the counterparties). The probability of all contracts at&nbsp;ER&amp;T being simultaneously &ldquo;out-of-the-money&rdquo; is highly unlikely due to offsetting positions within the portfolio. For this reason, the current exposure at any point in time is a more meaningful representation of the potential liability to Power under these guarantees. The current exposure consists of the net of accounts receivable and accounts payable and the forward value on open positions, less any margins posted. The current exposure from such liabilities
was $536 million and $549 million as of March&nbsp;31, 2006 and December&nbsp;31, 2005, respectively.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power is subject to collateral calls related to commodity contracts that are bilateral and is subject to certain creditworthiness standards as guarantor under performance guarantees for&nbsp;ER&amp;T&#39;s agreements. Changes in commodity prices, including fuel, emission allowances and electricity, can have an impact on</font></p>
<p align=center>23</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>contract terms and conditions, as margin calls on contracts entered into in the normal course of business will change as commodity prices change. As of March&nbsp;31, 2006, Power had paid cash margin of approximately $145 million and received cash margin of approximately $10 million. In addition, as of March&nbsp;31, 2006, letters of credit issued by Power were outstanding in the amount of approximately $556 million (including $195 million issued to&nbsp;PSE&amp;G) to satisfy trading collateral obligations and support various contractual and environmental obligations. Assuming no changes in forward energy prices and positions, Power&#39;s collateral requirements can be expected to decline over time as its contracts expire.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In the event of a deterioration of Power&#39;s credit rating to below investment grade, which represents at least a two level downgrade from its current ratings, many of these agreements allow the counterparty to demand that&nbsp;ER&amp;T provide further performance assurance, generally in the form of a letter of credit or cash. As of March&nbsp;31, 2006, if Power were to lose its investment grade rating and, assuming all counterparties to which&nbsp;ER&amp;T is &ldquo;out-of-the-money&rdquo; were contractually entitled to demand, and demanded, performance assurance, ER&amp;T could be required to post additional collateral in an amount equal to approximately $776 million. Power believes that it has sufficient access to liquidity to post such collateral, if necessary.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Due to an increase in commodity prices subsequent to March&nbsp;31, 2006, the amount of collateral posting requirements increased by approximately 35% as of April&nbsp;28, 2006.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Energy Holdings and/or Global have guaranteed certain obligations of their subsidiaries or affiliates, including the successful completion, performance or other obligations related to certain projects. The guaranteed obligations as of March&nbsp;31, 2006 and December&nbsp;31, 2005 are as follows:</font></p>

<table  cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0><tr bgcolor=#ffffff>

</table>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In September 2003, Energy Holdings completed the sale of PSEG Energy Technologies Inc. (Energy Technologies) and nearly all of its assets. However, Energy Holdings retained certain outstanding construction and warranty obligations related to ongoing construction projects previously performed by Energy Technologies. These construction obligations have performance bonds issued by insurance companies for which exposure is adequately supported by the outstanding letters of credit shown in the table above for PSEG Energy Technologies Asset Management Company&nbsp;LLC. As of March&nbsp;31, 2006, there were $22 million of such bonds outstanding related to uncompleted construction projects and other obligations. These performance bonds are not included in the $127 million of guaranteed obligations above.</font></p>
<p align=center>24</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In addition to the amounts discussed above, certain subsidiaries of Energy Holdings also have contingent obligations related to their respective projects, which are non-recourse to Energy Holdings.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Environmental Matters</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G and Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Hazardous Substances</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection (NJDEP) has regulations in effect concerning site investigation and remediation that require an ecological evaluation of potential damages to natural resources in connection with an environmental investigation of contaminated sites. These regulations may substantially increase the costs of environmental investigations and necessary remediation, particularly at sites situated on surface water bodies. PSE&amp;G, Power and respective predecessor companies own or owned and/or operate or operated certain facilities situated on surface water bodies, certain of which are currently the subject of remedial activities. The financial impact of these regulations is not currently estimable. However, neither&nbsp;PSE&amp;G nor Power anticipates that compliance with these regulations
will have a material adverse effect on their respective financial positions, results of operations or net cash flows.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The&nbsp;U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has determined that a six-mile stretch of the Passaic River in the area of Newark, New Jersey is a &lsquo;facility&#39; within the meaning of that term under the Federal Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act of 1980 (CERCLA). PSE&amp;G and certain of its predecessors conducted industrial operations at properties adjacent to the Passaic River facility. The operations included one operating electric generating station (Essex Site), one former generating station and four former manufactured gas plants (MGPs). PSE&amp;G&#39;s costs to clean up former MGPs are recoverable from utility customers through the societal benefits clause (SBC). PSE&amp;G has sold the site of the former generating station and obtained releases and indemnities for liabilities
arising out of the site in connection with the sale. The Essex Site was transferred to Power in August 2000. Power assumed any environmental liabilities of&nbsp;PSE&amp;G associated with the electric generating stations that&nbsp;PSE&amp;G transferred to it, including the Essex Site.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In 2003, the&nbsp;EPA notified&nbsp;41 potentially responsible parties (PRPs), including&nbsp;PSE&amp;G and Power, that it was expanding its assessment of the Passaic River Study Area to the entire&nbsp;17-mile tidal reach of the lower Passaic River. The&nbsp;EPA further indicated, with respect to&nbsp;PSE&amp;G, that it believed that hazardous substances had been released from the Essex Site and a former&nbsp;MGP located in Harrison, New Jersey (Harrison Site), which also includes facilities for&nbsp;PSE&amp;G&#39;s ongoing gas operations. The&nbsp;EPA estimated that its study would require five to eight years to complete and would cost approximately $20 million, of which it would seek to recover $10 million from the PRPs, including&nbsp;PSE&amp;G and Power. Power is evaluating recoverability of any disbursed amounts from
its insurance carriers.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Also, in 2003, PSEG, PSE&amp;G and&nbsp;56 other PRPs received a Directive and Notice to Insurers from the NJDEP that directed the PRPs to arrange for a natural resource damage assessment and interim compensatory restoration of natural resource injuries along the lower Passaic River and its tributaries pursuant to the New Jersey Spill Compensation and Control Act. The NJDEP alleged in the Directive that it had determined that hazardous substances had been discharged from the Essex Site and the Harrison Site. The NJDEP announced that it had estimated the cost of interim natural resource injury restoration activities along the lower Passaic River to approximate $950 million.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G and Power have indicated to both the&nbsp;EPA and NJDEP that they are willing to work with the agencies in an effort to resolve their respective claims and, along with approximately&nbsp;43 other PRPs, have executed an agreement with the&nbsp;EPA that provides for sharing the costs of the study between the government organizations and the PRPs. PSEG, PSE&amp;G and Power cannot predict what further</font></p>
<p align=center>25</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>actions, if any, or the costs or the timing thereof, that may be required with respect to the Passaic River or natural resource damages. However, such costs could be material.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>MGP Remediation Program</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G is currently working with the NJDEP under a program to assess, investigate and remediate environmental conditions at&nbsp;PSE&amp;G&#39;s former&nbsp;MGP sites (Remediation Program). To date, 38 sites have been identified as requiring some level of remedial action. In addition, the NJDEP has announced initiatives to accelerate the investigation and subsequent remediation of the riverbeds underlying surface water bodies that have been impacted by hazardous substances from adjoining sites. Specifically, in 2005, the NJDEP initiated a program on the Delaware River aimed at identifying the ten most significant sites for cleanup. One of the sites identified is a former&nbsp;MGP facility located in Camden, New Jersey. The Remediation Program is periodically reviewed, and the estimated costs are revised by&nbsp;PSE&amp;G
based on regulatory requirements, experience with the program and available remediation technologies. Since the inception of the Remediation Program in 1988 through March&nbsp;31, 2006, PSE&amp;G had expenditures of approximately $349 million.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>During the fourth quarter of 2005, PSE&amp;G refined the detailed site estimates. The cost of remediating all sites to completion, as well as the anticipated costs to address&nbsp;MGP-related material discovered in two rivers adjacent to former&nbsp;MGP sites, could range between $751 million and $796 million. No amount within the range was considered to be most likely. Therefore, $402 million was accrued as of March&nbsp;31, 2006, which represents the difference between the low end of the total program cost estimate of $751 million and the total incurred costs through March&nbsp;31, 2006 of $349 million. Of this amount, approximately $43 million was recorded in Other Current Liabilities and $359 million was reflected in Other Noncurrent Liabilities. The costs associated with the&nbsp;MGP Remediation Program have historically
been recovered through the&nbsp;SBC charges to&nbsp;PSE&amp;G ratepayers. As such, a $402 million Regulatory Asset was recorded. PSE&amp;G anticipates spending $44 million in 2006, $45 million in 2007 and an average of $35 million per year through 2016 to remediate MGP-related environmental conditions.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>New Jersey Clean Energy Program</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The&nbsp;BPU has approved a funding requirement for each New Jersey utility applicable to its Renewable Energy and Energy Efficiency programs for the years 2005 to 2008. The liability for the funding requirement has been recorded at the discounted present value. The costs associated with this program will be recovered from&nbsp;PSE&amp;G ratepayers over the four years and, therefore, a Regulatory Asset was also recorded. The liability for the funding requirement as of March&nbsp;31, 2006 and December&nbsp;31, 2005 was $313 million and $329 million, respectively.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Prevention of Significant Deterioration (PSD)/New Source Review (NSR)</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The&nbsp;PSD/NSR regulations, promulgated under the Clean Air Act (CAA), require major sources of certain air pollutants to obtain permits, install pollution control technology and obtain offsets, in some circumstances, when those sources undergo a &ldquo;major modification,&rdquo; as defined in the regulations. The Federal government is seeking to order companies allegedly not in compliance with the&nbsp;PSD/NSR regulations to install the best available control technology at the affected plants and to pay monetary penalties of up to approximately $27,500 for each day of continued violation.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The&nbsp;EPA and the NJDEP issued a demand in March 2000 under the&nbsp;CAA requiring information to assess whether projects completed since 1978 at the Hudson and Mercer coal-burning units were implemented in accordance with applicable&nbsp;PSD/NSR regulations. Power completed its response to the</font></p>
<p align=center>26</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>requests for information and, in January 2002, reached an agreement with the NJDEP and the&nbsp;EPA to resolve allegations of noncompliance with&nbsp;PSD/NSR regulations. Under that agreement, over the course of&nbsp;10 years, Power agreed to install advanced air pollution controls to reduce emissions of Sulfur Dioxide (SO</font><font color=#000000><small><sub>2</sub></small></font><font color=#000000>), Nitrogen Oxide (NOx), particulate matter and mercury from the coal-burning units at the Mercer and Hudson generating stations. The cost of the program was approximately $110 million for installation of selective catalytic reduction systems (SCRs) at Mercer, as well as additional expenditures of approximately $400 million to $500 million at Hudson and $150 million to $250 million at Mercer for other pollution control equipment to be installed by December&nbsp;31,
2006 and December&nbsp;31, 2012, respectively. Power also paid a $1.4 million civil penalty and has agreed to spend up to $6 million on supplemental environmental projects. The agreement resolving the&nbsp;NSR allegations concerning the Hudson and Mercer coal-fired units also resolved a dispute over Bergen&nbsp;2 regarding the applicability of&nbsp;PSD requirements and allowed construction of the unit to be completed and operations to commence.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power has notified the&nbsp;EPA and the NJDEP that it is evaluating the continued operation of the Hudson coal unit in light of changes in the energy and capacity markets, increases in the cost of pollution control equipment and other necessary modifications to the unit. Power will be unable to complete the installation of the pollution control equipment at Hudson by the December&nbsp;31, 2006 deadline. Power has proposed to the NJDEP and the&nbsp;EPA an alternative pollution reduction plan to permit Hudson to continue to operate on coal beyond December&nbsp;31, 2006. Discussions relating to this issue are ongoing. Power believes that system reliability concerns that&nbsp;PJM previously identified in the area may result in the unit continuing to operate after December&nbsp;31, 2006, however no assurances can be given regarding
the outcome of these discussions. Power cannot accurately determine all costs, including any penalties and limitations on operations, that may be associated with the continued operation of the Hudson unit beyond December&nbsp;31, 2006, but such costs could be material. The costs associated with the pollution control modifications for the Hudson unit have not been included in Power&#39;s forecasted capital expenditures.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Mercury Legislation</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>New Jersey and Connecticut have adopted standards for the reduction of emissions of mercury from coal-fired electric generating units. The Connecticut legislation requires coal-fired power plants in Connecticut to achieve either an emissions limit or a&nbsp;90% mercury removal efficiency through technology installed to control mercury emissions effective in July 2008. The regulations in New Jersey require coal-fired electric generating units in New Jersey to meet certain emission limits or reduce emissions by&nbsp;90% by December&nbsp;15, 2007. Companies that are parties to multi-pollutant reduction agreements are permitted to postpone such reductions on half of their coal-fired electric generating capacity until December&nbsp;15, 2012. Power has a multi-pollutant reduction agreement with the NJDEP as a result of a consent
decree that resolved issues arising out of the&nbsp;PSD and the&nbsp;NSR air pollution control programs at the Hudson, Mercer and Bergen facilities. Substantial uncertainty exists regarding the feasibility of achieving the reductions in mercury emissions required by the New Jersey regulations and Connecticut statute; however, the estimated costs of technology believed to be capable of meeting these emissions limits at Power&#39;s coal-fired unit in Connecticut and at its Mercer Station are included in Power&#39;s capital expenditure forecast. Total estimated costs for the project are estimated between $300 million and $360&nbsp;million.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>New Jersey Industrial Site Recovery Act (ISRA)</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Potential environmental liabilities related to subsurface contamination at certain generating stations have been identified. In the second quarter of 1999, in anticipation of the transfer of&nbsp;PSE&amp;G&#39;s generation-related assets to Power, a study was conducted pursuant to ISRA, which applies to the sale of certain assets. Power had a $51 million liability as of March&nbsp;31, 2006 and December&nbsp;31, 2005 related</font></p>
<p align=center>27</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>to these obligations, which is included in Other Noncurrent Liabilities on Power&#39;s Consolidated Balance Sheets and Environmental Costs on PSEG&#39;s Consolidated Balance Sheets.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Permit Renewals</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In June 2001, the NJDEP issued a renewed New Jersey Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NJPDES) permit for Salem, expiring in July 2006, allowing for the continued operation of Salem with its existing cooling water system. A renewal application prepared in accordance with the new Phase&nbsp;II 316(b) rule was filed with the NJDEP that allows the station to continue operating under its existing NJPDES permit until a new permit is issued. Power believes that its application to renew Salem&#39;s NJPDES permit demonstrates that the station meets the Phase&nbsp;II 316(b) rule&#39;s performance standards for reduction of impingement and entrainment through the station&#39;s existing cooling water intake technology and operations plus implemented restoration measures. Power believes that the application further demonstrates
that the station meets the Phase&nbsp;II 316(b) rule&#39;s site-specific determination standards without the benefits of restoration. If NJDEP were to require the installation of structures at the Salem facility to reduce cooling water intake flow commensurate with closed-cycle cooling as a result of an unfavorable decision in the Phase&nbsp;II litigation or otherwise, Power&#39;s application estimates that the costs associated with cooling towers for Salem are approximately $1 billion, of which Power&#39;s share would be approximately $575 million. These costs are not included in Power&#39;s currently forecasted capital expenditures.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>New Generation and Development</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power completed construction of a natural gas-fired generation plant in Linden, New Jersey, which commenced commercial operation on May&nbsp;1, 2006. Total costs, including interest capitalized during construction (IDC) of $214 million, were approximately $1.0 billion.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power also has contracts with outside parties to purchase upgraded turbines for Salem Units&nbsp;1 and&nbsp;2 and to purchase upgraded turbines and complete a power uprate for Hope Creek to modestly increase its generating capacity. Phase&nbsp;II of the Salem Unit&nbsp;2 turbine replacement is currently scheduled for 2008 concurrent with steam generator replacement and is anticipated to increase capacity by&nbsp;26 MW. Phase&nbsp;II of the Hope Creek turbine replacement is expected to be completed in 2007 along with the thermal power uprate and is expected to add approximately&nbsp;120 MW. Power&#39;s expenditures to date approximate $209 million (including&nbsp;IDC of $18 million) with an aggregate estimated share of total costs for these projects of $247 million (including&nbsp;IDC of $27 million). Timing, costs and results
of these projects are dependent on timely completion of work, timely approval from the&nbsp;NRC and various other factors.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Completion of the projects discussed above within the estimated time frames and cost estimates cannot be assured. Construction delays, cost increases and various other factors could result in changes in the operational dates or ultimate costs to complete.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Electroandes&nbsp;S.A. (Electroandes)</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>There is a&nbsp;35 MW expansion project on an existing hydro station under development at Electroandes, a generating facility in Peru. Construction is expected to be completed in 2007 at a total cost of approximately $30 million. The project is expected to be financed by a Global subsidiary with cash and non-recourse debt.</font></p>
<p align=center>28</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Basic Generation Service (BGS) Basic Gas Supply Service (BGSS)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power seeks to mitigate volatility in its results by contracting in advance for its anticipated electric output as well as its anticipated fuel needs.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As part of its objective, Power has entered into contracts to directly supply&nbsp;PSE&amp;G and other New Jersey Electric Distribution Companies (EDCs) with a portion of their respective&nbsp;BGS requirements through the New Jersey&nbsp;BGS auction process, described below. In addition to the&nbsp;BGS-related contracts, Power has entered into firm supply contracts with EDCs in Pennsylvania and Connecticut, as well as other firm sales and trading positions and commitments.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G and Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G is required to obtain all electric supply requirements for customers that do not purchase electric supply from third-party suppliers through the annual New Jersey&nbsp;BGS auctions. The&nbsp;BGS auction process is a statewide process in which all of the New Jersey EDCs participate. The&nbsp;BGS auctions are &ldquo;declining clock&rdquo; auctions, where the EDCs accept offers for the amount of electric supply bidders are willing to offer with higher prices at the beginning of the auction. The auction proceeds when the amount of supply bid exceeds what is needed. The offer price is subsequently lowered and the process continues in a series of steps. When the amount of supply bid by the prospective suppliers matches an&nbsp;EDC&#39;s electric supply needs, the auction ends. The&nbsp;BPU renders a decision whether
or not to accept the auction results within two business days of its conclusion.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G enters into the Supplier Master Agreement (SMA) with the winners of these&nbsp;BGS auctions within three business days of the&nbsp;BPU&#39;s approval. PSE&amp;G has entered into contracts with Power, as well as with other winning&nbsp;BGS suppliers, to purchase&nbsp;BGS for&nbsp;PSE&amp;G&#39;s anticipated load requirements. The winners of the auction are responsible for fulfilling all the requirements of a&nbsp;PJM Load Serving Entity (LSE) including capacity, energy, ancillary services, transmission and any other services required by&nbsp;PJM. BGS suppliers assume any migration risk and must satisfy New Jersey&#39;s renewable portfolio standards.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Through the&nbsp;BGS auctions, PSE&amp;G has contracted for its anticipated&nbsp;BGS-Fixed Price load, as follows:</font></p>
