<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Affiliate Loans and Advances</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG and Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of March&nbsp;31, 2006, Power had a note receivable due from PSEG of approximately $380 million, reflecting the investment of its excess cash with PSEG. As of December&nbsp;31, 2005, Power had a payable to PSEG of approximately $202 million for short-term funding needs. Interest Income and Interest Expense relating to these short-term funding activities was immaterial.</font></p>
<p align=center>48</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>NOTES TO CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br>
(UNAUDITED)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of March&nbsp;31, 2006 and December&nbsp;31, 2005, Energy Holdings had a note receivable due from PSEG of $58 million and $409 million, respectively, reflecting the investment of its excess cash with PSEG. Interest Income related to these borrowings was immaterial.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G and Services</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of March&nbsp;31, 2006 and December&nbsp;31, 2005, PSE&amp;G had advanced working capital to Services of approximately $33 million. This amount is included in Other Noncurrent Assets on&nbsp;PSE&amp;G&#39;s Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheets.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power and Services</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of March&nbsp;31, 2006 and December&nbsp;31, 2005, Power had advanced working capital to Services of approximately $18 million. This amount is included in Other Noncurrent Assets on Power&#39;s Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheets.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Other</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG and&nbsp;PSE&amp;G</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of March&nbsp;31, 2006 and December&nbsp;31, 2005, PSE&amp;G had receivables from PSEG of approximately $9 million and $6 million, respectively, related to amounts that PSEG had collected on&nbsp;PSE&amp;G&#39;s behalf.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG and Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of March&nbsp;31, 2006 and December&nbsp;31, 2005, Power had receivables from PSEG of approximately $4 million and $2 million, respectively, related to amounts that PSEG had collected on Power&#39;s behalf.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Global had loans of approximately $61 million and $60 million due from Prisma, a joint venture that is 50%-owned by Global and operates several biomass generation plants in Italy, as of March&nbsp;31, 2006 and December&nbsp;31, 2005, respectively. Included in the loan balances were $25 million and $24 million of accrued interest as of March&nbsp;31, 2006 and December&nbsp;31, 2005, respectively. These loans are guaranteed by an affiliate of Global&#39;s partner. Due to insufficient funds at the project level, total payments of $12 million due to Global on June&nbsp;30, 2005, September&nbsp;30, 2005 and December&nbsp;31, 2005 were not made. In August 2005, Global began seeking to enforce its rights under the guarantee by filing a legal action. In January 2006, Global and its partner entered into an agreement under which
Global agreed to forgive the guarantee of the project&#39;s loans and convert a portion of the loans into an equity interest. Global expects to close on the agreement in the second quarter of 2006. As a result, Global expects to increase its ownership percentage in Prisma to&nbsp;85% and obtain voting control of the project through proportionate representation on Prisma&#39;s Board of Directors. Once the transaction is completed, Global will begin consolidating Prisma.</font></p>
<p align=center>49</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>

<p align=center>51</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000><a name='Management'></font></b></p>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>ITEM&nbsp;2. MANAGEMENT&#39;S DISCUSSION&nbsp;AND ANALYSIS&nbsp;OF FINANCIAL<br>
CONDITION&nbsp;AND RESULTS&nbsp;OF OPERATIONS (MD&amp;A)</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Following are the significant changes in or additions to information reported in the 2005 Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K affecting the consolidated financial condition and the results of operations. This discussion refers to the Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements (Statements) and the related Notes to Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements (Notes) and should be read in conjunction with such Statements and Notes.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>This combined&nbsp;MD&amp;A is separately filed by Public Service Enterprise Group Incorporated (PSEG), Public Service Electric and Gas Company (PSE&amp;G), PSEG Power&nbsp;LLC (Power), and PSEG Energy Holdings&nbsp;L.L.C. (Energy Holdings). Information contained herein relating to any individual company is filed by such company on its own behalf. PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings each make representations only as to itself and make no representations as to any other company.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='Pending'>PENDING MERGER</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On December&nbsp;20, 2004, PSEG entered into an agreement and plan of merger (Merger Agreement) with Exelon Corporation (Exelon), a public utility holding company headquartered in Chicago, Illinois, whereby PSEG and its subsidiaries will be merged with and into Exelon (Merger). Under the Merger Agreement, each share of PSEG Common Stock will be converted into&nbsp;1.225 shares of Exelon Common Stock.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The Merger Agreement has been unanimously approved by both companies&#39; Boards of Directors. On July&nbsp;19, 2005, shareholders of PSEG voted to approve the Merger and on July&nbsp;22, 2005, shareholders of Exelon voted to approve the issuance of common shares to PSEG shareholders to effect the Merger.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Completion of the Merger is subject to approval by a number of governmental authorities. PSEG and Exelon have obtained all regulatory approvals from the principal agencies involved except the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC), U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) and the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities (BPU).</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The&nbsp;NRC proceeding is essentially complete, and an order is pending.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The&nbsp;DOJ is reviewing the Merger for competitive issues. It is anticipated that divestiture of some generating facilities will be required by the&nbsp;DOJ. Settlement discussions are being conducted in an effort to complete the&nbsp;DOJ process consistent with the mitigation proposal approved by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) and prior to an issuance of an order by the&nbsp;BPU.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In New Jersey, the&nbsp;BPU issued an order on June&nbsp;20, 2005, requiring Exelon and PSEG to prove that positive benefits flow to&nbsp;PSE&amp;G&#39;s customers and the State of New Jersey as a result of the Merger, and that, at a minimum, there be no adverse impact to competition, employees or reliability due to the Merger.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In late November 2005, the&nbsp;BPU concluded five public hearings at which representatives from business, environmental coalitions, non-profit organizations and consumer groups offered opinions about the Merger. Representatives of the four unions representing workers at PSEG testified in support of the Merger upon reaching an agreement with PSEG and Exelon that there will be no layoffs of union workers in New Jersey through the expiration of the current collective bargaining agreement on April&nbsp;30, 2011.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The hearings related to the&nbsp;BPU review of the Merger commenced on January&nbsp;4, 2006 at the New Jersey Office of Administrative Law and, in accordance with a schedule approved by the&nbsp;ALJ, concluded on March&nbsp;31, 2006. The&nbsp;PJM Market Monitor submitted his analysis of the adequacy of the proposal by PSEG and Exelon to mitigate market power of the new company through the sale of&nbsp;4,000&nbsp;MW of fossil generation and the virtual divestiture of&nbsp;2,600&nbsp;MW of nuclear generation, which is the market mitigation package that was approved by the FERC in its order on July&nbsp;1, 2005. During the hearings, other parties proposed additional divestiture and opposed the use of virtual divestiture to</font></p>
<p align=center>52</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>address market power issues. During the hearings, PSEG and Exelon also committed to provide rate credits to&nbsp;PSE&amp;G&#39;s customers of $120 million over three or four years, to maintain&nbsp;PSE&amp;G&#39;s capital expenditure program and to implement certain governance procedures. The&nbsp;ALJ&#39;s most recent schedule provides for initial briefs by April&nbsp;26, 2006 and for reply briefs by May&nbsp;10, 2006. Settlement discussions have resumed. Unless extended, New Jersey rules provide for an&nbsp;ALJ decision on June&nbsp;26, 2006 and a&nbsp;BPU decision on August&nbsp;9, 2006.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Commonwealth Edison&nbsp;Co. (ComEd), a wholly owned subsidiary of Exelon providing retail electric service in Illinois, is involved in regulatory proceedings in Illinois pertaining to the restructuring of the Illinois electric markets, which began in 1997. Since that time, the rates of ComEd have been reduced and capped, and ComEd transferred or sold its generation assets to third parties or to its affiliate, Exelon Generation&nbsp;LLC (Exelon Generation). Currently, the rate freeze for ComEd and contractual power supply obligations of Exelon Generation to ComEd expire December&nbsp;31, 2006. In January 2006, the Illinois Commerce Commission (ICC) approved, with certain modifications, a proposal by ComEd to procure power commencing January&nbsp;1, 2007 through an auction designed to reflect market rates. Various parties
to the proceeding, including the Illinois Attorney General and the Citizens Utility Board have requested the&nbsp;ICC to reconsider its decision, and have filed appeals to the courts for review of portions of the order. In addition, legislation has been introduced in the Illinois General Assembly to continue ComEd&#39;s rate freeze for an additional three years. ComEd has indicated that it believes that enactment of such legislation would violate Federal law and the&nbsp;U.S. Constitution. Nevertheless, ComEd has indicated that it cannot predict the outcome of these regulatory proceedings and legislative actions and that a rate freeze extension or other significant constraint on its ability to recover its power supply costs would have materially adverse financial and operating effects and would likely cause ComEd to resort to protection of the bankruptcy courts to continue as a going concern.
ComEd has also filed an electric distribution rate case with the&nbsp;ICC to reset its electric distribution rates effective January&nbsp;1, 2007 and to recover the purchase power costs incurred through the procurement auction discussed above. The results in this rate proceeding are not expected to be known until at least the third quarter of 2006 and an&nbsp;ICC Order in July 2006. The regulatory and political developments in Illinois could also have an effect on the timing or closing conditions of the Merger.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Exelon and PSEG presently expect to complete all of the regulatory reviews and close the Merger in the third quarter of 2006. The Merger Agreement provides that if the Merger is not consummated by June&nbsp;20, 2006, either party may terminate the Merger Agreement.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Although Exelon and PSEG believe that the expectations as to timing for the closing of the Merger described above are reasonable, no assurances can be given as to the timing of the receipt of any remaining regulatory approvals, that all required approvals will be received, or that conditions in future regulatory orders will be acceptable to the parties or not have materially adverse conditions. PSEG is committed to maintaining a viable stand-alone business strategy in the event the Merger does not close. Management believes PSEG will continue to operate successfully; however, inability to close the Merger could have an adverse impact on PSEG&#39;s and Power&#39;s credit ratings and could materially impact the financial condition, results of operations and cash flows of PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='Overview'>OVERVIEW&nbsp;OF 2006&nbsp;AND FUTURE OUTLOOK</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG&#39;s business consists of four reportable segments, which are&nbsp;PSE&amp;G, Power and the two direct subsidiaries of Energy Holdings: PSEG Global&nbsp;L.L.C. (Global) and PSEG Resources&nbsp;L.L.C. (Resources). The following is a discussion of the markets in which PSEG and its subsidiaries compete, the corporate strategy for the conduct of PSEG&#39;s businesses within these markets and significant events that have occurred during the first quarter of 2006 and expectations for the full year 2006 and beyond.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG develops a long-range growth target by building business plans and financial forecasts for each major business (PSE&amp;G, Power, Global and Resources). These plans and forecasts incorporate detailed estimates of revenues, operating and maintenance expenses, capital expenditures, financing costs and other material factors for each business. Key factors that may influence the performance of each business, such as fuel costs and forward power prices, are also incorporated. Sensitivity analyses</font></p>
<p align=center>53</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>are performed on the key variables that drive the businesses&#39; financial results in order to understand the impact of these assumptions on PSEG&#39;s projections. Once plans are in place, PSEG management monitors actual results and key variables and updates financial projections to reflect changes in the energy markets, the economy and regional and global conditions. PSEG management believes this monitoring and forecasting process enables it to alter operating and investment plans as conditions change.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>For the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006, PSEG had Income from Continuing Operations of $199 million, or $0.79 diluted per share, discussed below in Results of Operations. PSEG continues to project Income from Continuing Operations to range from $3.45 to $3.75 per share, excluding Merger-related costs and any potential impacts from mark-to-market (MTM) accounting although the range of expected earnings from each of PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings has been revised. Projected earnings as compared to the $3.64 per share in 2005 reflect higher earnings at Power, offset by modest reductions at&nbsp;PSE&amp;G and Energy Holdings and are based on a higher weighted average number of shares outstanding. The projections for 2006 also include $60 million to $70 million of expenses at the PSEG parent level, primarily for financing
costs. In addition, PSEG anticipates earnings per share growth to be in excess of&nbsp;10% per year for 2007 and 2008, which assumes continued improved operations at Power and reasonable outcomes in&nbsp;PSE&amp;G&#39;s regulatory proceedings.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG expects operating cash flows in 2006 and beyond to be sufficient to meet capital needs and dividend requirements and may employ any excess cash to reduce debt, invest in its businesses, increase dividends or, in the longer term, repurchase shares. On January&nbsp;17, 2006, PSEG announced an increase in its quarterly dividend from $0.56 to $0.57 per share for the first quarter of 2006. On April&nbsp;18, 2006, PSEG&#39;s Board of Directors approved a common stock dividend of $0.57 per share for the second quarter of 2006. These increases reflect an indicated annual dividend rate of $2.28 per share.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Several key factors that will drive PSEG&#39;s future success are energy, capacity and fuel prices, performance of Power&#39;s generating facilities, PSE&amp;G&#39;s ability to maintain a reasonable rate of return under its regulated rate structure and the stability of international economies for Energy Holdings.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G operates as an electric and gas public utility in New Jersey under cost-based regulation by the&nbsp;BPU for its distribution operations and by the FERC for its electric transmission and wholesale sales operations. Consequently, the earnings of&nbsp;PSE&amp;G are largely determined by the regulation of its rates by those agencies.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In February 2006, the&nbsp;BPU approved the results of New Jersey&#39;s annual Basic Generation Service (BGS)-Fixed Price (FP) and&nbsp;BGS-Commercial and Industrial Energy Price (CIEP) auctions and&nbsp;PSE&amp;G successfully secured contracts to provide the electricity requirements for the majority of its customers&#39; needs. BGS-FP and&nbsp;BGS-CIEP represent approximately&nbsp;84% and&nbsp;16%, respectively, of&nbsp;PSE&amp;G&#39;s&nbsp;BGS-eligible load.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The February 2006&nbsp;BGS-FP auction sought approximately one-third of&nbsp;PSE&amp;G&#39;s&nbsp;BGS-FP eligible load (2,882&nbsp;MW), since contracts for the other two-thirds were procured through the 2005 and 2004 auctions. The 2006 clearing price for&nbsp;PSE&amp;G&#39;s&nbsp;BGS-FP load was&nbsp;10.251 cents per kWh, an increase of approximately&nbsp;57% over the 2005 auction price. The term of the supply period is from June 2006 through May 2009. Due to the stabilizing effect of the portfolio approach (blending this year&#39;s price with the prices set in the auctions in 2005 and 2004), residential customers&#39; bills are expected to increase by approximately&nbsp;14% beginning June&nbsp;1, 2006.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On September&nbsp;30, 2005, PSE&amp;G filed a petition with the&nbsp;BPU seeking an overall&nbsp;3.78% increase in its gas base rates to appropriately recover the cost of gas delivery and to be effective June&nbsp;30, 2006. Approximately $55 million of the $133 million request is for an increase in book depreciation rates. The balance of the request will cover the return on increased plant investment, higher operating expenses and provide an&nbsp;11% return on equity. PSE&amp;G&#39;s current gas base rates have been in effect since January 2002. The current schedule provides for a decision on the gas base rate case from the&nbsp;BPU in December 2006, with the new rates effective immediately. PSE&amp;G cannot predict the timing and amount of any rate relief.</font></p>
<p align=center>54</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In addition, as part of the settlement of&nbsp;PSE&amp;G&#39;s electric base rate case in 2003, a $64 million annual depreciation rate credit was established. The excess depreciation reserve related to this credit was fully amortized as of December&nbsp;31, 2005. As part of the settlement, PSE&amp;G was required to make a financial filing with the&nbsp;BPU in November 2005 to support the elimination of the depreciation rate credit. The&nbsp;BPU issued an order on February&nbsp;7, 2006 and found that insufficient information had been provided to support the elimination of the credit at this time. The order permits&nbsp;PSE&amp;G to file, no later than June&nbsp;15, 2006, actual data through March&nbsp;31, 2006. The&nbsp;BPU will determine, based on the additional information, if the elimination of the depreciation rate credit
is warranted. The impact of not eliminating the depreciation rate credit reduces&nbsp;PSE&amp;G&#39;s earnings and cash flows by more than $5 million (pre-tax) per month. The timing and amount of an increase cannot be predicted with certainty. PSE&amp;G expects that final resolution of this case will likely be determined by the fall of 2006.</font></p>

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Action on
  PSE&amp;G&#39;s recent filings, including the excess depreciation rate credit
  and the gas base rate case, has been subject to ongoing delays. It appears that
  until the merger is resolved with the BPU, decisions on PSE&amp;G&#39;s requests
  may be difficult to achieve.</font></p>

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>For the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006, PSE&amp;G had Net Income of $78 million. Based on these results and the delayed decisions for the current Gas Base Rate Case and the elimination of the $64 million electric distribution rate credit (approximately $68 million based on current sales volumes), PSE&amp;G has lowered its previous guidance range for Income from Continuing Operations of $315 million to $335 million to a revised guidance range of $270 million to $290 million for 2006. These ranges exclude any merger-related costs.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The risks from this business generally relate to the treatment of the various rate and other issues by the state and federal regulatory agencies, specifically the&nbsp;BPU and FERC. In 2006 and beyond, PSE&amp;G&#39;s success will depend, in part, on its ability to maintain a reasonable rate of return, continue cost containment initiatives, maintain system reliability and safety levels and continue to recover with an adequate return the regulatory assets it has deferred and the investments it plans to make in its electric and gas transmission and distribution system. Since&nbsp;PSE&amp;G earns no margin on the commodity portion of its electric and gas sales through tariff agreements, there is no anticipated commodity price volatility for&nbsp;PSE&amp;G.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power is an electric generation and wholesale energy marketing and trading company that is focused on a generation market extending from Maine to the Carolinas and the Atlantic Coast to Indiana. Power&#39;s principal operating subsidiaries, PSEG Fossil&nbsp;LLC (Fossil), PSEG Nuclear&nbsp;LLC (Nuclear) and PSEG Energy Resources &amp; Trade&nbsp;LLC (ER&amp;T) are regulated by FERC. Through its subsidiaries, Power seeks to balance its generating capacity, fuel requirements and supply obligations through integrated energy marketing and trading, enhance its ability to produce low-cost energy through efficient nuclear operations and pursue modest growth based on market conditions. Changes in the operation of Power&#39;s generating facilities, fuel and capacity prices, expected contract prices, capacity factors or other assumptions
could materially affect its ability to meet earnings targets and/or liquidity requirements. In addition to the electric generation business described above, Power&#39;s revenues include gas supply sales under the basic gas supply service (BGSS) contract with&nbsp;PSE&amp;G.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As a merchant generator, Power&#39;s profit is derived from selling under contract or on the spot market a range of diverse products such as energy, capacity, emissions credits, congestion credits, and a series of energy-related products that the system operator uses to optimize the operation of the energy grid, known as ancillary services. Accordingly, the prices of commodities, such as electricity, gas, coal and emissions, as well as the availability of Power&#39;s diverse fleet of generation units to produce these products can have a material effect on Power&#39;s profitability.</font></p>

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power seeks to mitigate volatility in its results by contracting in advance for a significant portion of its anticipated electric output and fuel needs. Power believes this contracting strategy increases stability of earnings and cash flow. By keeping some portion of its output uncontracted, Power is able to retain some exposure to market changes as well as provide some protection in the event of unexpected generation outages.</font></p>
<p align=center>55</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In a changing market environment, this hedging strategy may cause Power&#39;s realized prices to be materially different than current market prices. At the present time, a significant portion of Power&#39;s existing contractual obligations, entered into during lower-priced periods, resulted in lower margins than would have been the case if no or little hedging activity had been conducted. Alternatively, in a falling price environment, this hedging strategy will tend to create margins in excess of those implied by the then current market.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>For Power&#39;s BGSS contracts, commodity costs are passed on to residential customers. Any differences from the BGSS contract prices are deferred by&nbsp;PSE&amp;G for future recovery. For commercial and industrial customers, a tariff structure is applied that is adjusted monthly based on the current New York Mercantile Exchange (NYMEX) prices. During the first quarter of 2006, market prices for natural gas were declining while the cost of gas in inventory was relatively stable, which reduced Power&#39;s margins as compared to 2005.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>For the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006, Power had Net Income of $112 million. Power has increased its previous guidance for Income from Continuing Operations of $475 million to $525 million to a revised guidance range of $500 million to $550 million for 2006, reflecting current results and anticipated continued improvements in the operating performance of its nuclear and fossil stations, strong energy markets and increased contracting opportunities. These increases will be partially offset by increases in depreciation and interest expense associated with the new Linden plant, which commenced commercial operation on May&nbsp;1, 2006 and a full year for the Bethlehem Energy Center (BEC), increased Operation and Maintenance costs and lower earnings from the Nuclear Decommissioning Trust (NDT) Funds. The guidance range does
not include merger-related costs and does not contemplate any potential earnings fluctuations that could occur due to MTM accounting being applied to Power&#39;s operations pursuant to Statement of Financial Accounting Standard (SFAS) No. 133, &ldquo;Accounting for Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities,&rdquo; as amended (SFAS&nbsp;133). See Note&nbsp;6. Risk Management of the Notes for additional information.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>A key factor in Power&#39;s ability to achieve its objectives is its capability to operate its nuclear and fossil stations at sufficient capacity factors to limit the need to purchase higher-priced electricity to satisfy its obligations. Power&#39;s ability to benefit from any future increases in market prices will depend, to a large extent, on efficient power plant operations, especially for its low-cost nuclear and coal-fired facilities. While these increases may have a potentially significant, beneficial impact on margins, they could also raise any replacement power costs that Power may incur in the event of unanticipated outages, and could also further increase liquidity requirements as a result of contract obligations. For additional information on liquidity requirements, see Liquidity and Capital Resources. In addition,
forward prices are constantly changing and therefore there is no assurance that Power will be able to contract its output at attractive prices.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Energy Holdings&#39; operations are principally conducted through its subsidiaries: Global, which has invested in international, rate-regulated distribution companies and domestic and international merchant generation companies, and Resources, which primarily invests in energy-related leveraged leases.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>For the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006, Energy Holdings had Income from Continuing Operations of $28 million. For the full year 2006, Energy Holdings has increased its previous guidance range for Income from Continuing Operations of $155 million to $175 million to a revised guidance range of $165 million to $185 million. The change from the original guidance is primarily due to improvements at the facilities operated by Texas Independent Energy, L.P. (TIE). The expected 2006 range is less than the 2005 Income from Continuing Operations of $199 million primarily due to a $43 million after-tax gain recognized in 2005 from Resources&#39; sale of its interest in Seminole Generation Station Unit&nbsp;2 (Seminole). The earnings range for 2006 excludes the expected gain on the sale of Global&#39;s two generating facilities
in Poland, Elektrocieplownia Chorzow Elcho&nbsp;Sp. Z o.o. (Elcho) and Elektrownia Skawina&nbsp;SA (Skawina), and any gain or loss on other potential asset sales as well as any potential finance costs associated with use of the proceeds. The guidance range also does not contemplate the potential earnings fluctuations that could occur due to&nbsp;MTM accounting being applied to Global&#39;s</font></p>
<p align=center>56</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>operations at&nbsp;TIE in Texas as the energy and gas contracts, which are backed by the physical capacity of the plants and sold in the normal course of business, must be marked to market pursuant to SFAS&nbsp;133. See Note&nbsp;6. Risk Management of the Notes for additional information related to this contract.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Included in the results for the quarter as compared to the same period in 2005 is an increase in the overall tax rate resulting from a change in the mix of domestic and foreign earnings. With a larger portion of the earnings coming from domestic sources, the full U.S. tax rate is applied to the earnings as compared to foreign earnings being taxed at a foreign tax rate for each country, which is generally lower. Energy Holdings expects its overall tax rate to increase as it continues to selectively monetize investments that no longer have a strategic fit.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Global</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Although Global continues to produce significant earnings and operating cash flow, the returns on several of the investments in its international portfolio have not been commensurate with the level of risk associated with international investments in developing energy markets. As a result, since 2003, Energy Holdings has refocused its strategy from one of growth to one that places emphasis on increasing the efficiency and returns of its existing assets.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Accordingly, Global continues to limit its capital spending, while focusing on operations and improved performance of existing businesses and is seeking to opportunistically monetize investments that may no longer have a strategic fit. On January&nbsp;31, 2006, Global entered into an agreement with&nbsp;CEZ a.s., the former Czech national utility company and the largest electric power company in central and eastern Europe, to sell its interest in two coal-fired plants in Poland, Elcho and Skawina. The sale is expected to close in the second quarter of 2006. Net proceeds from the sale are subject to various purchase price adjustments, foreign currency fluctuations and contingencies and are currently expected to be in excess of $300 million after taxes and transaction costs, which is in excess of the book value of the facilities
as of December&nbsp;31, 2005.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Global&#39;s success will depend, in part, upon its ability to mitigate risks of its international strategy. The economic and political conditions in certain countries where Global has investments present risks that may be different or more significant than those found in the&nbsp;U.S. including: renegotiation or nullification of existing contracts, changes in law or tax policy, interruption of business, nationalization, expropriation, war and other factors. Operations in foreign countries also present risks associated with currency exchange and convertibility, inflation and repatriation of earnings. In some countries in which Global has interests, economic and monetary conditions and other factors could affect its ability to convert its cash distributions to&nbsp;U.S. Dollars or other freely convertible currencies. Furthermore,
the central bank of any such country may have the authority to suspend, restrict or otherwise impose conditions on foreign exchange transactions or to limit distributions to foreign investors.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The capital requirements of Global&#39;s consolidated subsidiaries are primarily financed from internally generated cash flow within the projects and from locally sourced debt on a basis that is non-recourse to Global or limited discretionary investments by Energy Holdings.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Resources</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Resources primarily has invested in energy-related leveraged leases. Resources is focused on maintaining its current investment portfolio and does not expect to make any new investments. Resources&#39; ability to realize tax benefits associated with its leveraged lease investments is dependent upon taxable income generated by its affiliates. Resources&#39; earnings and cash flows are expected to decrease in the future as the investment portfolio matures. Resources faces risks with regard to the creditworthiness of its counterparties, specifically certain lessees that collectively comprise a substantial portion of Resources&#39; investment portfolio. Resources also faces risks related to potential changes in the current accounting and tax treatment of certain investments in leveraged leases. The manifestation of either of
these risks could cause a materially adverse effect on Resources&#39; strategy and its forecasted results of operations, financial position and net cash flows.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In December 2005, Resources sold its interest in the Seminole leveraged lease to Seminole Electric Cooperative Inc. for $287 million. The sale resulted in a $43 million after-tax gain. Net proceeds of $235</font></p>
<p align=center>57</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>million together with other funds were used on January&nbsp;30, 2006 to redeem Energy Holdings&#39; $309 million&nbsp;7.75% Senior Notes due in 2007.</font></p>

<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>(B)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>Other activities include non-segment amounts of PSEG (as parent company) and intercompany eliminations. Specific amounts include preferred securities dividends/preference unit distributions for&nbsp;PSE&amp;G in 2006 and 2005 and Energy Holdings in 2005, interest on certain financing transactions, Merger expenses and certain other administrative and general expenses at PSEG (as parent company).</font></td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>(C)</font></td>

See Note&nbsp;3. Discontinued Operations and Dispositions of the Notes.</font></td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>(D)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>Earnings Per Share of any segment does not represent a direct legal interest in the assets and liabilities allocated to any one segment but rather represents a direct interest in PSEG&#39;s assets and liabilities as a whole.</font></td></tr>
</table>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $81 million or $0.37 per share decrease in Income from Continuing Operations was primarily due to decreases at&nbsp;PSE&amp;G and Energy Holdings. The decrease at&nbsp;PSE&amp;G was due to a reduction in gas sales volumes due to milder weather in 2006 and reduced demand due to higher pricing. Also contributing to the decrease at&nbsp;PSE&amp;G was the full amortization of the excess depreciation reserve as of December&nbsp;31, 2005. The decrease at Energy Holdings was primarily due to the absence of income from withdrawal from the Eagle Point cogeneration partnership interest in January 2005, partially offset by improved operations at Energy Holdings&#39; facilities in Texas and South America. Power&#39;s earnings were relatively flat as compared to the same period in 2005 as increased revenues from higher sales in
the various power pools supported by improved nuclear operations were substantially offset by higher natural gas costs and unrealized losses on asset-backed transactions.</font></p>
<p align=center>58</p>

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG&#39;s results of operations are primarily comprised of the results of operations of its operating subsidiaries, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings, excluding changes related to intercompany transactions, which are eliminated in consolidation and certain financing costs at the parent company. For additional information on intercompany transactions, see Note&nbsp;13. Related-Party Transactions of the Notes. For a discussion of the causes for the variances at PSEG in the table above, see the discussions for&nbsp;PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings that follow.</font></p>

<td align=right valign=bottom nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
<td bgcolor=#e5ffff>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=right valign=bottom><font color=#000000>&mdash;</font></td>
<td bgcolor=#e5ffff>&nbsp;</td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>

<td align=right valign=bottom nowrap>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>
<td align=right valign=bottom nowrap><font color=#000000>$</font></td>

<td align=right valign=bottom nowrap><font color=#000000>$</font></td>

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Operating Revenues</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G has three sources of revenue: commodity revenues from the sales of energy to customers and in the&nbsp;PJM spot market; delivery revenues from the transmission and distribution of energy through its system; and other operating revenues from the provision of various services. The $166 million increase for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005 was due to increases of $178 million in commodity revenues, described below, and $2 million in other operating revenues, primarily related to appliance service contracts, partially offset by a $14 million decrease in delivery revenues.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Commodity</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G makes no margin on commodity sales as the costs are passed through to customers. The difference between gas costs and the amount provided by customers in revenues is deferred and collected from or returned to customers in future periods. Total commodity volumes and revenues are subject to market forces. Gas commodity prices fluctuate monthly for&nbsp;C&amp;I customers and annually through the BGSS tariff for residential customers. In addition, for residential gas customers, PSE&amp;G</font></p>
<p align=center>59</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>has the ability to adjust rates upward two additional times and downward at any time, if warranted, between annual BGSS proceedings. Electric commodity prices are set at the annual&nbsp;BGS auctions.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $178 million increase in commodity revenues for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was due to increases of $127 million in gas commodity revenues, primarily due to $287 million in higher BGSS prices offset by $114 million in lower volumes due to weather and a decrease of $46 million due to the expiration of the Third Party Shopping Incentive in July 2005. There is a corresponding $46 million increase in delivery revenues. Also contributing to the increase was $51 million in electric commodity revenues, primarily due to $43 million in higher&nbsp;BGS and Non-Utility Generation (NUG) prices and $8 million in higher&nbsp;NUG volumes due to operations.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Delivery</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $14 million decrease in delivery revenues for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was due to an $11 million decrease in electric revenues and a $3 million decrease in gas revenues.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $11 million decrease in electric delivery revenues was due primarily to $7 million in lower volumes due to weather and decreased prices of $4 million due to lower demand revenues. The $3 million decrease in gas delivery revenues was primarily due to $47 million in lower volumes due to weather and $6 million due to the impacts of price elasticity related to residential customers. These decreases were offset by $50 million in increased prices, $46 million of which was due primarily to the expiration of the Third Party Shopping Incentive in July 2005 and the Gas Cost Underrecovery Adjustment (GCUA) in January 2005.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Operating Expenses</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Energy Costs</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $207 million increase for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was comprised of increases of $168 million in gas costs and $38 million in electric costs. The increase in gas costs was caused by a $291 million or&nbsp;34% increase in gas prices offset by a $9 million decrease due to the expiration of the GCUA clause in January 2005, described above, and a $114 million decrease in sales volumes due primarily to weather. The electric increase is due to $25 million in higher prices for&nbsp;BGS and&nbsp;NUG purchases and $13 million in higher&nbsp;NUG volumes.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Operation and Maintenance</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $6 million increase for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was due primarily to $6 million in increased labor and fringe benefits.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Depreciation and Amortization</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $17 million increase for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was due primarily to the absence of amortization of an excess electric distribution depreciation reserve regulatory liability which ended December&nbsp;31, 2005.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Income Taxes</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $21 million decrease for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was primarily due to lower pre-tax income.</font></p>
<p align=center>60</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Operating Revenues</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $237 million increase for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was due to increases of $151 million in generation revenues, $84 million in gas supply revenues and $2 million in trading revenues.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Generation</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Generation revenues increased $151 million for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, primarily due to higher revenues of approximately $143 million from higher prices and increased sales volumes in the various power pools supported by improved nuclear operations, largely due to Hope Creek&#39;s higher capacity factor, and the commencement of the commercial operations of&nbsp;BEC in July 2005. This increase was partially offset by reduced load being served under the&nbsp;BGS contracts. Also, contributing to the increase was approximately $23 million from Reliability Must-Run (RMR) revenues.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Gas Supply</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Gas supply revenues increased $84 million for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, principally due to higher prices under the BGSS contract for gas and pipeline capacity partially offset by lower demand, largely resulting from customer conservation and a warmer winter heating season in 2006.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Operating Expenses</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Energy Costs</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Energy Costs represent the cost of generation, which includes fuel purchases for generation as well as purchased energy in the market, and gas purchases to meet Power&#39;s obligation under its BGSS contract with&nbsp;PSE&amp;G.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Energy Costs increased approximately $217 million for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, primarily due to an increase of $130 million from higher prices on a reduced volume of gas purchased to satisfy Power&#39;s BGSS obligations and increased generation costs of $87 million, reflecting higher prices and volumes of fossil fuel and unrealized losses on asset-backed transactions.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Operation and Maintenance</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Operation and Maintenance expense increased $8 million for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, primarily due to higher maintenance expense of $20 million related to outages in 2006 at certain of the fossil plants that satisfy peaking requirements partially offset</font></p>
<p align=center>61</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>by a $12 million decrease in labor costs due to a reduction in personnel at the nuclear generating facilities and other Power locations.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Depreciation and Amortization</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $5 million increase for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was primarily due to the&nbsp;BEC facility being placed into service in July 2005 and a higher depreciable asset base in 2006 at Nuclear.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Other Income</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Other Income increased $10 million for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, primarily due to increased realized gains and income related to the&nbsp;NDT Funds and higher interest on margin call deposits.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Other Deductions</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Other Deductions increased $11 million for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, primarily due to increased realized losses and miscellaneous expenses related to the&nbsp;NDT Funds.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Interest Expense</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Interest Expense increased $12 million for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, due primarily to lower capitalized interest costs in 2006 related to commencement of operations of the&nbsp;BEC facility in July 2005.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Income Taxes</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Income Taxes decreased $3 million for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, primarily due to lower pre-tax income.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Loss from Discontinued Operations, net of tax</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The Loss from Discontinued Operations of $7 million for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 represents the operating results of Waterford.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Operating Revenues</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $1 million decrease for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was due to lower revenues at Resources of $14 million primarily due to a reduction in income due</font></p>
<p align=center>62</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>to the December 2005 sale of Resources&#39; interest in Seminole and the absence of a $6 million pre-tax gain on the sale of Resources&#39; limited partnership interest in three Solar Electric Generating Systems projects recognized in 2005.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Offsetting the decrease was higher revenues at Global of $13 million, which was the net result of increased revenues consisting of a $46 million increase at&nbsp;TIE due to an increase in the average price of megawatt hours, a $15 million increase at Sociedad Austral de Electricidad&nbsp;S.A. (SAESA) in Chile due to increased tariffs and gigawatt hours and a $2 million increase at Electroandes due to higher energy sales, partially offset by decreased revenues due to the absence of $37 million of income received in 2005 from the withdrawal from the Eagle Point cogeneration partnership interest and a $14 million decrease related to Global&#39;s sale of a&nbsp;35% interest in Dhofar Power Company&nbsp;S.A.O.C. (Dhofar Power) through a public offering on the Omani Stock Exchange in April 2005, reducing its ownership interest
to&nbsp;46% and thus accounting for the investment under the equity method of accounting following the sale.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Operating Expenses</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Energy Costs</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $56 million increase for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was primarily due to a $47 million increase at&nbsp;TIE resulting from an increase in production gas prices, a $10 million increase related to SAESA due to increased volume and increases in energy costs due to higher spot price offset by a $3 million decrease related to the deconsolidation of Dhofar Power.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Operation and Maintenance</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $8 million decrease for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was primarily due to a $10 million decrease at&nbsp;TIE resulting from a scheduled hot gas path inspection outage that occurred in the first quarter of 2005, and a $2 million decrease related to the deconsolidation of Dhofar Power partially offset by other operation and maintenance items.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Depreciation and Amortization</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $2 million decrease for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was due to a $3 million decrease related to the deconsolidation of Dhofar Power offset by a $1 million increase related to depreciation expense on completed projects at SAESA.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Income from Equity Method Investments</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $2 million increase for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was primarily due to stronger results from Chilquinta Energia&nbsp;S.A. and Rio Grande Energia&nbsp;S.A. due to stronger foreign currency rates.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Other Income</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $4 million decrease for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was primarily due to the absence of $6 million of interest income received in 2005 from asset sales, partially offset by foreign currency transaction gains.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Interest Expense</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $8 million decrease for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was primarily due to a decrease in debt outstanding.</font></p>
<p align=center>63</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Income Taxes</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The $2 million decrease for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was primarily due to a higher effective rate for Global due to a change in mix of domestic and international earnings.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Income from Discontinued Operations, net of tax</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In January 2006, Energy Holdings entered into an agreement to sell its interest in two coal-fired plants in Poland, Elcho and Skawina. Income from Discontinued Operations related to Elcho and Skawina for the quarters ended March&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005 was $4 million and $12 million, respectively, net of tax. See Note&nbsp;3. Discontinued Operations and Dispositions of the Notes for additional information.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Other</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>To supplement the Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements presented in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the&nbsp;U.S. (GAAP), PSEG and Energy Holdings use the non-GAAP measure of Earnings Before Interest and Taxes (EBIT).</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG&#39;s and Energy Holdings&#39; Management each reviews EBIT internally to evaluate performance and manage operations and believes that the inclusion of this non-GAAP financial measure provides consistent and comparable measures to help shareholders understand current and future operating results. PSEG and Energy Holdings urge shareholders to carefully review the GAAP financial information included as part of this Quarterly Report.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Global</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The following table summarizes Global&#39;s capital at risk as of March&nbsp;31, 2006 and December&nbsp;31, 2005 and net contributions to EBIT and non-recourse interest for the quarters ended March&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005 in the following regions.</font></p>

<div align=left>
<p><font color=#000000><hr color=#000000 noshade align=left width=48 size=0></font></p>
</div>
<table width=100% cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0><tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>(A)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>Total Capital at Risk includes Global&#39;s gross investments less non-recourse debt at the project level.</font></td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>(B)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>For investments accounted for under the equity method of accounting, includes Global&#39;s share of net earnings, including Interest Expense and Income Tax Expense. The $31 million decrease in EBIT in North America for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was primarily due to $37 million of income from the withdrawal from the Eagle Point cogeneration partnership interest in 2005.</font></td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>(C)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>Non-recourse interest is Interest Expense on debt that is non-recourse to Global.</font></td></tr>
</table>
<p align=center>64</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<table width=100% cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0><tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>(D)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>The Total Capital at Risk includes amounts relating to Elcho and Skawina as the sale has not been completed and therefore there is still Capital at Risk in Poland. EBIT and Non-Recourse Interest exclude amounts relating to Elcho and Skawina. EBIT was $15 million and $25 million for the quarters ended March&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, respectively. Non-Recourse Interest was $9 million for the quarters ended March&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005. See Note&nbsp;3. Discontinued Operations and Dispositions of the Notes.</font></td></tr>
</table>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='Liquidity'>LIQUIDITY&nbsp;AND CAPITAL RESOURCES</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The following discussion of liquidity and capital resources is on a consolidated basis for PSEG, noting the uses and contributions of PSEG&#39;s three direct operating subsidiaries, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Operating Cash Flows</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>For the
  quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006, PSEG&#39;s operating cash flow increased
  by approximately $258 million from $657 million to $915 million, as compared
  to the same period in 2005, due to net increases from its subsidiaries as discussed
  below.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G&#39;s operating cash flow increased approximately $46 million from $226 million to $272 million for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, primarily due to change in working capital requirements and higher recovery of regulatory assets.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power&#39;s
  operating cash flow increased approximately $318 million from $364 million to
  $682 million for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006, as compared to the same
  period in 2005, due to decreased margin requirements and a decrease in fuel
  inventory due to decreased commodity prices and a reduction in natural gas inventory
  following the winter heating season.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Energy Holdings&#39; operating cash flow decreased approximately $91 million from $92 million to $1 million for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, due primarily to the timing of tax benefits and payments and the absence of proceeds from the sale of investments and investment distributions.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Common Stock Dividends</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Dividend payments on common stock for the quarters ended March&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005 were $0.57 and $0.56 per share, respectively, and totaled approximately $143 million and $134 million, respectively. Future dividends declared will be dependent upon PSEG&#39;s future earnings, cash flows, financial requirements, alternative investment opportunities and other factors.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Short-Term Liquidity</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of March&nbsp;31, 2006, PSEG and its subsidiaries had a total of approximately $3.7 billion of committed credit facilities with approximately $3 billion of available liquidity under these facilities. In</font></p>
<p align=center>65</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>addition, PSEG and&nbsp;PSE&amp;G have access to certain uncommitted credit facilities. Each of the facilities is restricted to availability and use to the specific companies as listed below.</font></p>

<div align=left>
<p><font color=#000000><hr color=#000000 noshade align=left width=48 size=0></font></p>
</div>
<table width=100% cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0><tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>(A)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>Expected to be renewed with expiration in April 2007.</font></td></tr>
