<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>(B)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>PSEG/Power joint and several co-borrower facility.</font></td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>(C)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings/Global/Resources joint and several co-borrower facility.</font></td></tr>
<tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>(D)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>These amounts relate to letters of credit outstanding.</font></td></tr>
</table>
<p align=center>66</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG and&nbsp;PSE&amp;G</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG and&nbsp;PSE&amp;G believes it has sufficient liquidity to fund its short-term cash needs.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of March&nbsp;31, 2006, Power had loaned $380 million to PSEG in the form of an intercompany loan.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>During the first quarter of 2006, Power&#39;s required margin postings decreased for sales contracts entered into in the normal course of business as commodity prices declined. The required margin postings will fluctuate based on volatility in commodity prices. Should commodity prices rise, additional margin calls may be necessary relative to existing power sales contracts. As Power&#39;s contract obligations are fulfilled, liquidity requirements are reduced. Power believes that it has sufficient liquidity to fund its short-term cash needs.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In addition, ER&amp;T maintains agreements that require Power, as its guarantor under performance guarantees, to satisfy certain creditworthiness standards. In the event of a deterioration of Power&#39;s credit rating to below investment grade, many of these agreements allow the counterparty to demand that&nbsp;ER&amp;T provide performance assurance, generally in the form of a letter of credit or cash. Providing this support would increase Power&#39;s costs of doing business and could restrict the ability of&nbsp;ER&amp;T to manage and optimize Power&#39;s asset portfolio. Power believes it has sufficient liquidity to meet any required posting of collateral resulting from a credit rating downgrade. See Note&nbsp;5. Commitments and Contingent Liabilities of the Notes for further information.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As of March&nbsp;31, 2006, Energy Holdings had loaned $58 million of excess cash to PSEG. In addition, Energy Holdings and its subsidiaries had $70 million in cash, including $3 million invested offshore as of March&nbsp;31, 2006.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>External Financings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>During the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006, PSEG issued approximately&nbsp;266,000 shares of its common stock under its Dividend Reinvestment Program and Employee Stock Purchase Program for approximately $17 million.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In February 2006, PSEG redeemed $154 million of its Subordinated Debentures underlying $150 million of Enterprise Capital Trust&nbsp;II, Floating Rate Capital Securities and its common equity investment in the trust.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On March&nbsp;1, 2006, PSE&amp;G repaid at maturity $148 million of its&nbsp;6.75% Series&nbsp;UU First and Refunding Mortgage Bonds.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In March 2006, PSE&amp;G Transition Funding&nbsp;LLC (Transition Funding) repaid approximately $36 million of its transition bonds.</font></p>
<p align=center>67</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In April 2006, Power repaid at maturity $500 million of its&nbsp;6.875% Senior Notes.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In January 2006, Energy Holdings redeemed its $309 million of its&nbsp;7.75% Senior Notes due in 2007.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On February&nbsp;17,
  2006, the maturity of the Odessa&ndash;Ector Power Partners, L.P (Odessa) debt
  was extended to December&nbsp;31, 2009. Interest on the debt is based on a spread
  (currently&nbsp;2.25%) above LIBOR. As of September&nbsp;29, 2006, Odessa&#39;s
  interest rate will be swapped to a fixed rate of&nbsp;5.4275%.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Debt Covenants</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG&#39;s, PSE&amp;G&#39;s, Power&#39;s and Energy Holdings&#39; respective credit agreements generally contain customary provisions under which the lenders could refuse to advance loans in the event of a material adverse change in the borrower&#39;s business or financial condition.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>As explained in more detail below, these credit agreements may also contain maximum debt-to-equity ratios, minimum cash flow tests and other restrictive covenants and conditions to borrowing. Compliance with applicable financial covenants will depend upon the respective future financial position, level of earnings and cash flows of PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings, as to which no assurances can be given. The ratios presented below are for the benefit of the investors of the related securities to which the covenants apply. They are not intended as a financial performance or liquidity measure.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Financial covenants contained in PSEG&#39;s credit facilities include a ratio of debt (excluding non-recourse project financings, securitization debt and debt underlying preferred securities and including commercial paper and loans, certain letters of credit and similar instruments) to total capitalization (including preferred securities outstanding) covenant. This covenant requires that at the end of any quarterly financial period, such ratio not be more than&nbsp;70.0%. As of March&nbsp;31, 2006, PSEG&#39;s ratio of debt to capitalization (as defined above) was&nbsp;57.5%.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Financial covenants contained in&nbsp;PSE&amp;G&#39;s credit facilities include a ratio of long-term debt (excluding securitization debt, long-term debt maturing within one year, and short-term debt) to total capitalization covenant. This covenant requires that at the end of any quarterly financial period, such ratio will not be more than&nbsp;65.0%. As of March&nbsp;31, 2006, PSE&amp;G&#39;s ratio of long-term debt to total capitalization (as defined above) was&nbsp;46.2%.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>In addition, under its First and Refunding Mortgage (Mortgage), PSE&amp;G may issue new First and Refunding Mortgage Bonds against previous additions and improvements, provided that its ratio of earnings to fixed charges calculated in accordance with its Mortgage is at least&nbsp;2 to&nbsp;1, and/or against retired Mortgage Bonds. As of March&nbsp;31, 2006, PSE&amp;G&#39;s Mortgage coverage ratio was&nbsp;4.66 to&nbsp;1 and the Mortgage would permit up to approximately $1.7 billion aggregate principal amount of new Mortgage Bonds to be issued against previous additions and improvements.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG and Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Financial covenants contained in the PSEG/Power joint and several credit facility include a ratio of debt to total capitalization for each specific borrower. This facility has a&nbsp;70.0% debt to total capitalization covenant for PSEG (calculated as set forth above) and a&nbsp;65% debt to total capitalization covenant for Power. The Power ratio is the same debt to total capitalization calculation as set forth above for PSEG except common equity is adjusted for the $986 million Basis Adjustment (see</font></p>
<p align=center>68</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheets). This covenant requires that at the end of any quarterly financial period, such ratio will not exceed&nbsp;65.0%. As of March&nbsp;31, 2006, Power&#39;s ratio of debt to capitalization (as defined above) was&nbsp;48.8%.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Energy Holdings entered into a $150 million five-year bank revolving credit agreement in June 2005 with a covenant requiring the ratio of Earnings Before Interest, Taxes, Depreciation and Amortization (EBITDA) to fixed charges to be greater than or equal to&nbsp;1.75. As of March&nbsp;31, 2006, Energy Holdings&#39; coverage of this covenant was&nbsp;2.76. Additionally, Energy Holdings must maintain a ratio of net debt to EBITDA of less than&nbsp;5.25. As of March&nbsp;31, 2006, Energy Holdings&#39; ratio under this covenant was&nbsp;3.55. Energy Holdings is a co-borrower under this facility with Global and Resources, which are joint and several obligors. The terms of the agreement include a pledge of Energy Holdings&#39; membership interest in Global, restrictions on the use of proceeds related to material sales of assets
and the satisfaction of certain financial covenants. Net cash proceeds from asset sales in excess of&nbsp;5% of total assets of Energy Holdings during any&nbsp;12-month period must be used to repay any outstanding amounts under the credit agreement. Net cash proceeds from asset sales during any&nbsp;12-month period in excess of&nbsp;10% of total assets must be retained by Energy Holdings or used to repay the debt of Energy Holdings, Global or Resources.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Credit Ratings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The current ratings of securities of PSEG and its subsidiaries are shown below and reflect the respective views of the rating agencies. Any downward revision or withdrawal may adversely affect the market price of PSEG&#39;s, PSE&amp;G&#39;s, Power&#39;s and Energy Holdings&#39; securities and serve to materially increase those companies&#39; cost of capital and limit their access to capital. All ratings have a stable outlook unless otherwise noted. (N) denotes a negative outlook, (P) denotes a positive outlook and (WD) denotes a credit watch developing, indicating that ratings could be raised or lowered. There is no assurance that the ratings will continue for any given period of time or that they will not be revised by the rating agencies, if, in their respective judgments, circumstances so warrant. Each rating given by
an agency should be evaluated independently of the other agencies&#39; ratings. The ratings should not be construed as an indication to buy, hold or sell any security.</font></p>

<p align=center>69</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Other Comprehensive Loss (OCL)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>For the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006, PSEG, Power and Energy Holdings had&nbsp;OCL of $136 million, $133 million and $2 million, respectively, due primarily to a reduction in the net unrealized losses on derivatives accounted for as hedges in accordance with SFAS&nbsp;133, and unrealized gains and losses in the&nbsp;NDT Funds at Power and foreign currency translation adjustments at Energy Holdings.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>During the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006, Power&#39;s&nbsp;OCL decreased from $487 million to $354 million. The primary cause was a decrease of approximately $115 million related to the change in market value of energy and related contracts that qualify for hedge accounting that were entered into by Power in the normal course of business. During the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006, the decrease in gas and electric prices has resulted in a reduction in unrealized losses on many of those contracts, which are recorded in&nbsp;OCL.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='Capital'>CAPITAL REQUIREMENTS</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>It is expected that the majority of funding for capital requirements of&nbsp;PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings will come from their respective internally generated funds. The balance will be provided by the issuance of debt at the respective subsidiary or project level and, for&nbsp;PSE&amp;G and Power, equity contributions from PSEG. PSEG does not expect to contribute any additional equity to Energy Holdings. Projected construction and investment expenditures for PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings are consistent with amounts disclosed in the Annual Reports on Form&nbsp;10-K of PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>During the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006, PSE&amp;G made approximately $108 million of capital expenditures, primarily for reliability of transmission and distribution systems. The $108 million excludes approximately $8 million spent on cost of removal.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>During the
  quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006, Power made approximately $67 million of capital
  expenditures (excluding $51 million for nuclear fuel), primarily related to
  various projects at Fossil and Nuclear.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>During the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006, Energy Holdings incurred approximately $14 million of capital expenditures, primarily related to SAESA.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000><a name='Accounting'>ACCOUNTING MATTERS</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>For information related to recent accounting matters, see Note&nbsp;2. Recent Accounting Standards of the Notes.</font></p>
<p align=center>70</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000><a name='Qualitative'>ITEM&nbsp;3. QUALITATIVE&nbsp;AND QUANTITATIVE DISCLOSURES<br>
ABOUT MARKET RISK</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The market risk inherent in PSEG&#39;s, PSE&amp;G&#39;s, Power&#39;s and Energy Holdings&#39; market-risk sensitive instruments and positions is the potential loss arising from adverse changes in foreign currency exchange rates, commodity prices, equity security prices and interest rates as discussed in the Notes to Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements (Notes). It is the policy of each entity to use derivatives to manage risk consistent with its respective business plans and prudent practices. PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings have a Risk Management Committee (RMC) comprised of executive officers who utilize an independent risk oversight function to ensure compliance with corporate policies and prudent risk management practices.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Additionally, PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings are exposed to counterparty credit losses in the event of non-performance or non-payment. PSEG has a credit management process, which is used to assess, monitor and mitigate counterparty exposure for PSEG and its subsidiaries. In the event of non- performance or non-payment by a major counterparty, there may be a material adverse impact on PSEG and its subsidiaries&#39; financial condition, results of operations or net cash flows.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Except as discussed below, there were no material changes from the disclosures in the Annual Reports on Form&nbsp;10-K of PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Commodity Contracts</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The availability and price of energy commodities are subject to fluctuations from factors such as weather, environmental policies, changes in supply and demand, state and federal regulatory policies, market rules and other events. To reduce price risk caused by market fluctuations, Power enters into supply contracts and derivative contracts, including forwards, futures, swaps and options with approved counterparties. These contracts, in conjunction with demand obligations, help reduce risk and optimize the value of owned electric generation capacity.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Normal Operations and Hedging Activities</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power enters into physical contracts, as well as financial contracts, including forwards, futures, swaps and options designed to reduce risk associated with volatile commodity prices. Commodity price risk is associated with market price movements resulting from market generation demand, changes in fuel costs and various other factors.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Under SFAS&nbsp;No. 133, &ldquo;Accounting for Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities&rdquo;, as amended (SFAS&nbsp;133), changes in the fair value of qualifying cash flow hedge transactions are recorded in OCL, and gains and losses are recognized in earnings when the underlying transaction occurs. Changes in the fair value of derivative contracts that do not meet hedge criteria under SFAS&nbsp;133 and the ineffective portion of hedge contracts are recognized in earnings currently. Additionally, changes in the fair value attributable to fair value hedges are similarly recognized in earnings.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Many non-trading contracts qualify for the normal purchases and normal sales exemption under SFAS&nbsp;133 and are accounted for upon settlement.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Trading</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power maintains a strategy of entering into trading positions to optimize the value of its portfolio of generation assets, gas supply contracts and its electric and gas supply obligations. Power engages in physical and financial transactions in the electricity wholesale markets and executes an overall risk management strategy to mitigate the effects of adverse movements in the fuel and electricity markets. In addition, Power has non-asset based trading activities, which have significantly decreased over the past year. These contracts also involve financial transactions including swaps, options and futures. These</font></p>
<p align=center>71</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>activities are marked to market in accordance with SFAS&nbsp;133 with gains and losses recognized in earnings.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Value-at-Risk (VaR) Models</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power uses VaR models to assess the market risk of its commodity businesses. The portfolio VaR model for Power includes its owned generation and physical contracts, as well as fixed price sales requirements, load requirements and financial derivative instruments. VaR represents the potential gains or losses, under normal market conditions, for instruments or portfolios due to changes in market factors, for a specified time period and confidence level. Power estimates VaR across its commodity businesses.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Power manages its exposure at the portfolio level. Its portfolio consists of owned generation, load-serving contracts (both gas and electric), fuel supply contracts and energy derivatives designed to manage the risk around generation and load. While Power manages its risk at the portfolio level, it also monitors separately the risk of its trading activities and its hedges. Non-trading mark-to-market (MTM) VaR consists of&nbsp;MTM derivatives that are economic hedges, some of which qualify for hedge accounting. The&nbsp;MTM derivatives that are not hedges are included in the trading VaR.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The VaR models used by Power are variance/covariance models adjusted for the delta of positions with a&nbsp;95% one-tailed confidence level and a one-day holding period for the&nbsp;MTM trading and non-trading activities and a&nbsp;95% one-tailed confidence level with a one-week holding period for the portfolio VaR. The models assume no new positions throughout the holding periods, whereas Power actively manages its portfolio.</font></p>

<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Other Supplemental Information Regarding Market Risk</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The following presentation of the activities of Power is included to address the recommended disclosures by the energy industry&#39;s Committee of Chief Risk Officers. For additional information, see Note&nbsp;6. Risk Management of the Notes.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The following table describes the drivers of Power&#39;s energy trading and marketing activities and Operating Revenues included in its Condensed Consolidated Statement of Operations for the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2006. Normal operations and hedging activities represent the marketing of electricity available from Power&#39;s owned or contracted generation sold into the wholesale market. As the information in this table highlights, MTM activities represent a small portion of the total Operating Revenues for Power. Activities accounted for under the accrual method, including normal purchases and sales, account for the majority of the revenue. The&nbsp;MTM activities reported here are those relating to changes in fair value due to external movement in prices.</font></p>
<p align=center>72</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>

<div align=left>
<p><font color=#000000><hr color=#000000 noshade align=left width=48 size=0></font></p>
</div>
<table width=100% cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0><tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>(A)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>Includes derivative contracts that Power enters into to hedge anticipated exposures related to its owned and contracted generation supply, all asset-backed transactions and hedging activities, but excludes owned and contracted generation assets.</font></td></tr>
</table>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The following table indicates Power&#39;s energy trading assets and liabilities, as well as Power&#39;s hedging activity related to asset-backed transactions and derivative instruments that qualify for hedge accounting under SFAS&nbsp;133, its amendments and related guidance. This table presents amounts segregated by portfolio which are then netted for those counterparties with whom Power has the right to offset and therefore, are not necessarily indicative of amounts presented on the Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheets since balances with many counterparties are subject to offset and are shown net on the Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheets regardless of the portfolio in which they are included.</font></p>

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Wherever possible, fair values for these contracts were obtained from quoted market sources. For contracts where no quoted market exists, modeling techniques were employed using assumptions reflective of current market rates, yield curves and forward prices as applicable to interpolate certain prices. The effect of using such modeling techniques is not material to Power&#39;s financial results.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The following table identifies losses on cash flow hedges that are currently in Accumulated Other Comprehensive Loss, a separate component of equity. Power uses forward sale and purchase contracts, swaps and firm transmission rights (FTRs) contracts to hedge forecasted energy sales from its generation stations and its contracted supply obligations. Power also enters into swaps, options and futures transactions to hedge the price of fuel to meet its fuel purchase requirements for generation. PSEG, Power and Energy Holdings are subject to the risk of fluctuating interest rates in the normal course of business. PSEG&#39;s policy is to manage interest rate risk through the use of fixed rate debt, floating rate debt and interest rate derivatives. The table also provides an estimate of the losses that are expected to be reclassified
out of Accumulated Other Comprehensive Loss and into earnings over the next twelve months.</font></p>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000>Cash Flow Hedges Included in Accumulated Other Comprehensive Loss<br>
As of March&nbsp;31, 2006</font></b></p>

<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Credit Risk</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The following table provides information on Power&#39;s credit exposure, net of collateral, as of March&nbsp;31, 2006. Credit exposure is defined as any positive results of netting accounts receivable/accounts payable and the forward value on open positions. It further delineates that exposure by the credit rating of the counterparties and provides guidance on the concentration of credit risk to individual counterparties and an indication of the maturity of a company&#39;s credit risk by credit rating of the counterparties.</font></p>
<p align=center>74</p>

<table width=100% cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 border=0><tr bgcolor=#ffffff>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>(A)</font></td>
<td align=left valign=top nowrap>&nbsp;</td>
<td align=left valign=top><font color=#000000>Counterparty is&nbsp;PSE&amp;G.</font></td></tr>
</table>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The net exposure listed above, in some cases, will not be the difference between the current exposure and the collateral held. A counterparty may have posted more collateral than the outstanding exposure, in which case there would not be exposure.</font></p>
<p align=center>75</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000><a name='Controls'>ITEM&nbsp;4. CONTROLS&nbsp;AND PROCEDURES</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Disclosure Controls and Procedures</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings have established and maintain disclosure controls and procedures which are designed to provide reasonable assurance that information required to be disclosed is recorded, processed, summarized and reported within the time periods specified in the&nbsp;SEC&#39;s rules and forms and that material information relating to each company, including their respective consolidated subsidiaries, is accumulated and communicated to the respective company&#39;s management, including the Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer of each company by others within those entities to allow timely decisions regarding required disclosure. PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings have established a disclosure committee which is made up of several key management employees and which reports
directly to the Chief Financial Officer and Chief Executive Officer of each respective company. The committee monitors and evaluates the effectiveness of these disclosure controls and procedures. The Chief Financial Officer and Chief Executive Officer of each company have evaluated the effectiveness of the disclosure controls and procedures as of March&nbsp;31, 2006 and, based on this evaluation, have concluded that the disclosure controls and procedures were effective in providing reasonable assurance during the period covered in these quarterly reports.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Internal Controls</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>During the first quarter of 2006, PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings each made enhancements to internal controls. These enhancements, which are expected to improve the design and operational effectiveness of control processes for financial reporting, included significant changes to internal controls including enhanced policies and procedures related to the derivative accounting process.</font></p>
<p align=center>76</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>

<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=center><b><font color=#000000><a name='Other'>ITEM&nbsp;5. OTHER INFORMATION</a></font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Certain information reported under the 2005 Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K is updated below. Additionally, certain information is provided for new matters that have arisen subsequent to the filing of the 2005 Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K. References are to the related pages on the Form&nbsp;10-K as printed and distributed.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>Federal Regulation</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC)</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><u><font color=#000000>Market Power</font></u></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>2005 Form&nbsp;10-K, Page&nbsp;16. </font></b></i><font color=#000000>On February&nbsp;28, 2006, PSEG Power Connecticut&nbsp;LLC (Power Connecticut) filed its triennial updated market power report with the FERC. The FERC has not yet acted on this filing. Further, once the PSEG and Exelon merger is consummated, all PSEG and Exelon subsidiaries holding market based rate authority will be required to provide appropriate updates of their market power analyses to the FERC.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G and Power</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><u><font color=#000000>PJM Schedule&nbsp;12 Filing</font></u></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On January&nbsp;5, 2006, in accordance with its Tariff and Operating Agreement, PJM filed (1)&nbsp;a report identifying the &ldquo;Responsible Customers&rdquo; that will be required to pay for certain transmission upgrades approved through&nbsp;PJM&#39;s Regional Transmission Expansion Planning (RTEP) process and the percentage of the project cost that will be allocated to such Responsible Customers; and (2)&nbsp;revised tariff sheets to identify such allocations. On March&nbsp;1, 2006, PJM submitted an amendment to the January&nbsp;5, 2006 filing by (1)&nbsp;adding certain additional transmission upgrades that have been vetted through the PJM&nbsp;RTEP process and approved by the&nbsp;PJM Board of Managers in November 2004, and (2)&nbsp;updating the cost allocations by adding a new Responsible Customer. PJM has requested
an effective date of May&nbsp;30, 2006 for these Schedule&nbsp;12 tariff sheets.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On March&nbsp;31, 2006, PSE&amp;G and Power, filed comments to the&nbsp;PJM Schedule&nbsp;12 filing, indicating general support for the filing but expressing concern with regard to certain aspects of the cost allocation methodology used by&nbsp;PJM, which may result in a disproportionate allocation of costs to load in the eastern portion of&nbsp;PJM. PSEG, PSE&amp;G and Power are unable to predict the outcome of this proceeding.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><u><font color=#000000>Regional through and out rates (RTOR)</font></u></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>2005 Form&nbsp;10-K, Page&nbsp;17. </font></b></i><font color=#000000>A trial-type hearing, encompassing a review of the actual amount of lost revenues to be recovered via the Seams Elimination Charge/Cost Adjustment/Assignment (SECA) mechanism, is now scheduled to commence on May&nbsp;2, 2006, with an initial decision by August&nbsp;11, 2006. In addition, in March 2006, PSE&amp;G and Power entered into a settlement with a limited group of parties in&nbsp;PJM, which settlement was certified to the FERC, under which the parties have agreed that, notwithstanding the resolution of the SECA hearing at the FERC, the parties will agree to pay and collect&nbsp;80% of SECA revenues. PSE&amp;G has deferred the collection of any SECA revenues on its books. It is expected that&nbsp;PSE&amp;G&#39;s potential refund exposure as
a result of the FERC SECA hearing (should the FERC determine that the amount being collected under SECA has been too high), and Power&#39;s potential gain under the same scenario would likely offset each other. Thus, at the present time, the SECA hearing is not expected to have a significant adverse impact on&nbsp;PSEG.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Currently, discussions are underway regarding the potential elimination of RTORs between&nbsp;PJM and the New York Independent System Operators. PSEG, PSE&amp;G and Power are unable to predict the outcome of this proceeding.</font></p>
<p align=center>78</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><u><font color=#000000>PJM Reliability Pricing Model (RPM)</font></u></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>2005 Form&nbsp;10-K, Page&nbsp;17.</font></b></i><font color=#000000> On April&nbsp;20, 2006, the FERC issued an order acknowledging the existence of issues in the current (non-locational) capacity market design in&nbsp;PJM, and setting&nbsp;PJM&#39;s&nbsp;RPM filing for both a technical conference and a hearing. PSEG, PSE&amp;G and Power are unable to predict the outcome of this proceeding.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><u><font color=#000000>PJM Stated Rate Filing</font></u></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>2005 Form&nbsp;10-K, Page&nbsp;18. </font></b></i><font color=#000000>On July&nbsp;1, 2005, PJM filed with FERC a proposal to change the rate design for its administrative cost recovery from a formula rate, which allocates&nbsp;PJM&#39;s administrative costs to its members on a yearly basis, to a stated rate of&nbsp;39 cents per&nbsp;MW-hour. On August&nbsp;31, 2005, FERC accepted these changes subject to the provision of further cost-of-service data by&nbsp;PJM within&nbsp;60 days to demonstrate that its stated rate is a just and reasonable prediction of its costs for future years. PJM provided this cost-of-service data on November&nbsp;30, 2005. Several parties, including&nbsp;PSE&amp;G, Power, the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities (BPU) and the New Jersey Ratepayer Advocate (RPA), submitted comments and protests
regarding&nbsp;PJM&#39;s filing, which protested the filing and requested that FERC order an evidentiary hearing regarding the filing. Settlement discussions were conducted over the course of several months, and a settlement in principle amongst all parties in the proceeding has been reached. This settlement establishes a base stated rate that is significantly lower than&nbsp;PJM&#39;s filed rate, establishes a rate for&nbsp;PJM&#39;s proposed second control center, and establishes a revised protocol to govern future interaction between the&nbsp;PJM Finance Committee, PJM management, PJM&#39;s Board of Managers, and the&nbsp;PJM membership, revisions which will result in the Finance Committee having greater access to&nbsp;PJM financial information and greater input into&nbsp;PJM&#39;s financial decision making processes. The settlement was filed with the FERC for its approval on April&nbsp;18,
2006.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Power</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><u><font color=#000000>Reliability Must Run (RMR) Status</font></u></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>PJM</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>2005 Form&nbsp;10-K, Page&nbsp;18.</font></b></i><font color=#000000> Effective February&nbsp;24, 2005, subject to refund and hearing, Power began to collect a monthly fixed payment of $3.3 million, net of operating margins for the Sewaren&nbsp;1, 2, 3 and&nbsp;4 and Hudson&nbsp;1 units. A detailed settlement was filed with FERC on September&nbsp;23, 2005 that permits Power to recover annual fixed costs of approximately $19 million and $14.5 million for the Sewaren and Hudson units, respectively, plus reimbursements of Power&#39;s expenditures in connection with certain construction at the units that are necessary to maintain reliability, offset by certain revenues earned in&nbsp;PJM&#39;s energy market. FERC accepted this settlement retroactive to February&nbsp;24, 2005. On March&nbsp;28, 2006, Power filed a refund
report with FERC seeking to recover $11 million paid to&nbsp;PJM. The FERC has not yet acted on the refund report filing.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>New England</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>2005 Form&nbsp;10-K, Page&nbsp;19. </font></b></i><font color=#000000>On November&nbsp;17, 2004, Power Connecticut, a wholly owned indirect subsidiary of Power, filed a request for&nbsp;RMR treatment for the New Haven Harbor generation station and Unit&nbsp;2 at the Bridgeport Harbor generation station. Beginning on January&nbsp;14, 2005, when FERC issued an order accepting this filing, subject to refund and hearing, Power Connecticut began collecting monthly fixed payments of approximately $1.6 million and $3.9 million for reliability services provided by the Bridgeport Harbor Station, Unit&nbsp;2 and the New Haven Harbor Station, respectively, net of operating margins at the units. On June&nbsp;17, 2005, Power Connecticut filed revised studies supporting monthly recovery of $1.3 million and $3.3 million for the
Bridgeport Harbor and New Haven Harbor units, respectively.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On June&nbsp;20, 2005, FERC issued an order on rehearing of its January&nbsp;14, 2005 order and reversed its prior conclusion that Power Connecticut&#39;s November&nbsp;17, 2004 filing would become effective only after a&nbsp;60-day notice period. Instead, the rehearing order allowed the filing to become effective as of November&nbsp;18, 2004, which permits Power Connecticut two additional months of&nbsp;RMR compensation.</font></p>
<p align=center>79</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left><font color=#000000>On November&nbsp;28, 2005, FERC denied rehearing of its June&nbsp;20, 2005 order. Certain parties opposing the&nbsp;RMR filing, on January&nbsp;27, 2006, sought judicial review of the FERC&#39;s orders in this proceeding.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>FERC assigned this matter to an Administrative Law Judge (ALJ) for hearings that were scheduled to commence on April&nbsp;19, 2006. Power Connecticut and the affected intervenors have, nonetheless, continued to engage in settlement discussions. On April&nbsp;21, 2006, Power Connecticut, the Connecticut Department of Public Utility Control, the Connecticut Office of Consumer Counsel and the&nbsp;ISO New England Inc. filed with the FERC a Joint Stipulation and Settlement Agreement and Motion for Expedited Consideration. The Joint Stipulation and Settlement, if approved by the FERC, resolves all issues set for hearing by the FERC in this proceeding, as well as issues for which rehearing had been sought and for which petitions for review have been filed with appellate courts. The Joint Stipulation and Settlement Agreement,
among other things, provides for an Annual Fixed Revenue Requirement of approximately $37 million for New Haven Harbor and $14 million for Bridgeport Harbor. These rates, subject to certain limited exceptions specified in the Joint Stipulation and Settlement Agreement, will be fixed for the term of the&nbsp;RMR Cost of Service Agreements, which may be extended through June 2011 if the FERC approves the offer of settlement filed with it on March&nbsp;6, 2006. If the settlement is not approved by the FERC, these rates will remain in effect until the FERC implements a Locational Installed Capacity Market or an alternative, unless the&nbsp;RMR Cost of Service Agreements are earlier terminated in accordance with their terms and conditions. Initial comments concerning the Joint Stipulation and Settlement Agreement are to be filed with the FERC by May&nbsp;11, 2006, with reply comments being due
by May&nbsp;22, 2006.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>While Power Connecticut believes that the Joint Stipulation and Settlement Agreement, which is either supported or unopposed by most of the active parties to this proceeding, is likely to be approved by the FERC, it cannot predict a final outcome at this time.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>NRC</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><u><font color=#000000>Recirculation Pump</font></u></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>2005 Form&nbsp;10-K, Page&nbsp;21. </font></b></i><font color=#000000>In a letter to the&nbsp;NRC dated January&nbsp;9, 2005, Power committed to install vibration-monitoring equipment on Hope Creek&#39;s &lsquo;B&#39; Reactor Recirculation Pump prior to the unit&#39;s return to service to address pump vibration concerns and replace the pump&#39;s shaft during the next refueling outage or any sooner outage of sufficient duration. This commitment was the subject of a January&nbsp;11, 2005 Confirmatory Action Letter from the&nbsp;NRC. The shaft was replaced during the Hope Creek outage in April 2006. On April&nbsp;20, 2006, the&nbsp;NRC issued a Closure of Confirmatory Action Letter indicating that all of the commitments were completed.</font></p>
<p align=left><b><font color=#000000>State Regulation</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 (PUHCA) Repeal</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>2005 Form&nbsp;10-K, Page&nbsp;21. </font></b></i><font color=#000000>On March&nbsp;31, 2006, the&nbsp;BPU issued draft proposed rules in this proceeding. Specifically, these proposed rules would preserve and further codify the&nbsp;BPU&#39;s access to both utility and utility holding company system books and records, establish ring-fencing measures around the utility, seek to separate the corporate boards of directors between the utility and its holding company system, and address issues regarding the extent of the&nbsp;BPU&#39;s oversight of service agreements between a utility and its holding company system. Comments to the&nbsp;BPU on these draft proposed rules are due on May&nbsp;22, 2006. PSE&amp;G anticipates filing extensive comments on these proposed rules. PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings are not
able to predict the outcome of these proceedings at this time.</font></p>
<p align=center>80</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b><font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G</font></b></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>BGS Auction Review</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The&nbsp;BPU has initiated a proceeding to review the annual procurement process for&nbsp;BGS for all of the New Jersey Electric Distribution Companies. The&nbsp;BPU will review the procurement process as well as the policy issues directly related thereto. The BPU will consider written submissions as well as testimony supplied in the legislative-type hearing held on this issue on April&nbsp;28, 2006. A&nbsp;BPU decision is expected by June&nbsp;7, 2006. PSE&amp;G cannot predict the outcome of this proceeding.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Electric Distribution Financial Review</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>2005 Form&nbsp;10-K, Page&nbsp;22. </font></b></i><font color=#000000>Based on the Electric Base Rate Case approved in July 2003, PSE&amp;G recorded a regulatory liability in the second quarter of 2003 by reducing its depreciation reserve for its electric distribution assets by $155 million and amortized this liability from August&nbsp;1, 2003 through December&nbsp;31, 2005. The $64 million annual amortization of this liability resulted in a reduction of Depreciation and Amortization expense. PSE&amp;G filed for the elimination of the $64 million (based on 2003 test year sales volumes) electric distribution rate credit effective January&nbsp;1, 2006, subject to&nbsp;BPU approval, including a review of&nbsp;PSE&amp;G&#39;s earnings and other relevant financial information. Based on current sales volumes, the amount
approximates $68 million.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>The&nbsp;BPU
  issued an order on February&nbsp;7, 2006 that found that insufficient information
  had been provided to support the elimination of the rate credit. The order permits&nbsp;PSE&amp;G
  to file, no later than June&nbsp;15, 2006, actual data through March&nbsp;31,
  2006. The&nbsp;BPU will determine, based on the additional information, if the
  elimination of the rate credit is warranted. The impact of not eliminating the
  depreciation rate credit reduces&nbsp;PSE&amp;G&#39;s earnings and cash flows
  by more than $5 million (pre-tax) per month. PSE&amp;G expects to file the data
  with the&nbsp;BPU in mid-May 2006. Action on PSE&amp;G&#39;s recent filings,
  including the excess depreciation rate credit, has been subject to ongoing delays.
  It appears that until the merger is resolved with the BPU, decisions on PSE&amp;G&#39;s
  revenue requests may be difficult to achieve.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Basic Gas Supply Service (BGSS) Filings</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>2005 Form&nbsp;10-K, Page&nbsp;22. </font></b></i><font color=#000000>On March 8, 2006 a meeting of the&nbsp;PSE&amp;G, BPU Staff and the&nbsp;RPA was held regarding the BGSS rates for the 2005/2006 period. PSE&amp;G addressed the&nbsp;RPA&#39;s discovery concerns, however the&nbsp;RPA requested that the BGSS not be finalized until the merger case was resolved.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>Pursuant to the existing schedule at the&nbsp;OAL, the&nbsp;RPA&#39;s testimony was to be filed on March&nbsp;15, 2006. The&nbsp;RPA failed to file and subsequently argued that the BGSS be held in abeyance until the merger case is resolved. The&nbsp;ALJ directed the&nbsp;RPA to file a motion, which was subsequently filed. The motion requested that the BGSS proceeding be stayed, or that it be consolidated with the gas base rate case. PSE&amp;G filed its reply on April&nbsp;5, 2006 arguing that the issues of the two proceedings are unrelated and that the&nbsp;RPA&#39;s motion had no merit.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Gas Base Rate Case</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>2005 Form&nbsp;10-K, Page&nbsp;23. </font></b></i><font color=#000000>On September&nbsp;30, 2005, PSE&amp;G filed a petition with the&nbsp;BPU seeking an overall&nbsp;3.78% increase in its gas base rates to cover the cost of gas delivery to be effective June&nbsp;30, 2006. Approximately $55 million of the $133 million request is for an increase in book depreciation rates. The balance of the request will cover the return on increased plant investment, higher operating expenses and provide an&nbsp;11% return on equity. PSE&amp;G&#39;s current gas base rates have been in effect since January 2002.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>PSE&amp;G presented a detailed overview of the filing to the&nbsp;BPU and the&nbsp;RPA in October 2005 and subsequent to the presentation signed an agreement with the&nbsp;BPU Staff providing for transfer of the matter to&nbsp;OAL and agreeing to have the matter settled or ready for a&nbsp;BPU decision before September&nbsp;28, 2006.</font></p>
<p align=center>81</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On February&nbsp;28, 2006, PSE&amp;G filed its revised testimony and exhibits for&nbsp;12 months of actual test year data. The schedule now calls for a&nbsp;BPU decision by December 2006. Action on PSE&amp;G&#39;s recent filings, including the gas base rate case, has been subject to ongoing delays. It appears that until the merger is resolved with the BPU, decisions on PSE&amp;G&#39;s revenue requests may be difficult to achieve.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>CAS Cost Recovery Mechanism</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>2005 Form&nbsp;10-K, Page&nbsp;23. </font></b></i><font color=#000000>The New Jersey Electric Discount and Energy Competition Act (EDECA) required that the&nbsp;BPU provide electric and natural gas customers with the opportunity to choose a supplier for some or all electric or natural gas customer account services (CAS). In July 2004, PSE&amp;G filed a petition with the&nbsp;BPU to implement the&nbsp;CAS Cost Recovery Mechanism for both its electric and gas operations to recover $4 million of&nbsp;CAS costs and accumulated interest resulting from implementing&nbsp;PSE&amp;G&#39;s dual billing for its delivery costs and for the third-party suppliers&#39; commodity charges as a result of customer migration from&nbsp;PSE&amp;G. In September 2004, the case was transferred to the&nbsp;OAL as a contested case. A pre-hearing
conference was held on December&nbsp;20, 2005 at which time a schedule was established. On April&nbsp;7, 2006, a settlement agreement was reached and filed with the&nbsp;ALJ. Upon final agreement with the&nbsp;ALJ, the case will be presented to the&nbsp;BPU for final determination. Under the agreement, PSE&amp;G will recover approximately $3.4 million in previously deferred costs.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Carbon Dioxide (CO</font></b><b><font color=#000000><small><sub>2</sub></small></font></b><b><font color=#000000>) Emissions</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>2005 Form&nbsp;10-K, Page&nbsp;27. </font></b></i><font color=#000000>Several states, primarily in the Northeastern&nbsp;U.S., are developing state-specific or regional legislative initiatives to stimulate CO</font><font color=#000000><small><sub>2</sub></small></font><font color=#000000> emission reductions in the electric power industry. New York initiated the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative (RGGI) in April 2003. Currently, in the RGGI, seven Northeastern states have signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) intended to cap and reduce CO</font><font color=#000000><small><sub>2</sub></small></font><font color=#000000> emissions from the electric power sector in the RGGI region. A draft model rule was issued on March&nbsp;23, 2006 but stakeholder comments are being received and the model rule has not been finalized.
States are expected to enact legislation and/or regulation representing, at least, the minimum requirements stipulated in the&nbsp;MOU. The NJDEP in 2005 finalized amendments to its regulations governing air pollution control that would designate CO</font><font color=#000000><small><sub>2</sub></small></font><font color=#000000> as an air contaminant subject to regulation. The RGGI program is scheduled to start in 2009. The outcome of this initiative cannot be determined at this time; however, adoption of stringent CO</font><font color=#000000><small><sub>2</sub></small></font><font color=#000000> emission reduction requirements in the Northeast could materially impact Power&#39;s operation of its fossil fuel-fired electric generating units.</font></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><b><font color=#000000>Remedial Investigation/Feasibility Study</font></b></i></p>
<p align=left>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<font color=#000000>On March&nbsp;9, 2006, the&nbsp;EPA sent&nbsp;PSE&amp;G, Power and approximately&nbsp;157 other entities a notice that the&nbsp;EPA considered each of the entities to be a&nbsp;PRP with respect to contamination in Berry&#39;s Creek in Bergen County, New Jersey and requesting that the PRPs perform a Remedial Investigation/Feasibility Study (RI/FS) on Berry&#39;s Creek and the connected tributaries and wetlands. Berry&#39;s Creek flows through approximately&nbsp;6.5 miles of areas that have been used for a variety of industrial purposes and landfills. The&nbsp;EPA estimates that the study could be completed in approximately five years at a total cost of approximately $18 million. PSE&amp;G and Power are unable to predict the outcome of this matter, however, the related costs are not expected to be material.</font></p>
<p align=center>82</p>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">

<td>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td>

<DOCUMENT>
<TYPE>EX-10
<SEQUENCE>2
<FILENAME>ex10.txt
<DESCRIPTION>EXHIBIT 10
<TEXT>

<PAGE>


              RETENTION PROGRAM FOR KEY EMPLOYEES OF PUBLIC SERVICE
                         ENTERPRISE GROUP INCORPORATED

                             AMENDED APRIL 18, 2006

                  The Retention Program for Key Employees of Public Service
Enterprise Group Incorporated is intended to reward selected officers and key
employees of Public Service Enterprise Group Incorporated ("Enterprise") who
continue to provide services to Enterprise after the date of the Merger
Agreement between Exelon Corporation and Enterprise. This Program automatically
incorporates all applicable restrictions of the American Jobs Creation Act of
2004 (the "AJCA") and guidance issued by the Department of Treasury under the
AJCA, and Enterprise will amend the Program to the extent necessary to comply
with such requirements. The AJCA, which became law on October 22, 2004, provides
that payments due to a change in the ownership or effective control of the
employer must comply with guidance issued by the Department of Treasury. The
AJCA and any Treasury guidance issued to implement the AJCA may result in
additional restrictions on a Key Employee's rights relating to compensation
considered to be deferred under this Program. The timing under which a Key
Employee has a right to receive any payment under the Program will automatically
be modified, and a Key Employee's rights under the Program shall be limited as
necessary to conform to any requirements under the AJCA and such guidance.

                  Subject to the foregoing, the Program shall be operated and
administered in accordance with the following terms and conditions:

                  1.       DEFINITIONS.

                           a. "Annual Base Salary" means the annual
         compensation, excluding bonuses, commissions, overtime, incentive
         payments, perquisite allowances, non-monetary awards, director fees and
         other fees, relocation expense reimbursements, auto allowances, imputed
         income from group term life insurance, and any other non-recurring
         items, paid to or on behalf of a Key Employee for services rendered to
         Enterprise, before reduction for compensation deferred pursuant to all
         qualified, nonqualified and cafeteria plans of Enterprise.

                           b. "Cause" means (i) the willful and continued
         failure of a Key Employee substantially to perform his duties, (ii)
         willful engagement in gross misconduct materially and demonstrably
         injurious to Enterprise, (iii) willful violation of Enterprise's
         Standards of Integrity or other applicable corporate code of conduct,
         or (iv) conviction of a felony. No act or failure to act on the part of
         a Key Employee shall be considered "willful" unless it is done or
         omitted by the Key Employee in bad faith or without reasonable belief
         that the Key Employee's action or omission was in the best interest of
         Enterprise.

                           c. "Committee" means the Organization and
         Compensation Committee of the Board of Directors of Enterprise.

                           d. "Earned Date" means the date that is ninety (90)
         days after the Effective Time.




<PAGE>


                           e. "Effective Time" has the meaning ascribed to such
         term in the Merger Agreement.

                           f. "Key Employee" means an officer or key employee of
         Enterprise who meets the requirements of eligibility for participation
         in the Program and who is selected by the Committee to receive a Key
         Employee Retention Payment.

                           g. "Key Employee Retention Payment" means the cash
         payment paid to Key Employees and Qualifying Key Employees under the
         Program.

                           h. "Merger Agreement" means the merger agreement
         between Exelon Corporation and Enterprise, dated as of December 20,
         2004.

                           i. "Merger Agreement Date" means the date on which
         the Merger Agreement is executed by Exelon Corporation and Enterprise.

                           h. "Program" means this Retention Program for Key
         Employees of Enterprise.

                           h. "Qualifying Key Employee" means those Key
         Employees who are continuously employed with Enterprise and Exelon
         Corporation from the date of the Merger Agreement through the Earned
         Date.

                           i. All capitalized terms not otherwise defined herein
         shall be ascribed the definition ascribed to each such term pursuant to
         the Merger Agreement.

                  2. ELIGIBILITY. The Committee, in its sole discretion, shall
select, from those officers and key employees of Enterprise who are employed by
Enterprise as of the Merger Agreement Date, Key Employees to participate in the
Program. The Committee may delegate the selection of Key Employees who are not
officers and the establishment of Key Employee Retention Payments to the Chief
Executive Officer of Enterprise.

                  3. AMOUNT. The Committee, in its sole discretion, shall
determine the total amount of the Key Employee Retention Payment to be paid to
each Key Employee, which amount shall not be less than 40% of the Key Employee's
Annual Base Salary and shall not exceed 150% of the Key Employee's Annual Base
Salary. For purposes of the Program, the amount of a Key Employee's Annual Base
Salary shall be determined as of the Merger Agreement Date.

                  4. PAYMENT SCHEDULE.

                           a. Except as provided in subparagraph c, Enterprise
         shall pay one half (1/2) of the Key Employee Retention Payments to the
         respective Key Employees within sixty (60) days following the first
         anniversary of the Merger Agreement Date.

                           b. Not later than the first business day following
         the Earned Date, Exelon Corporation shall pay the remaining amount of
         the Key Employee Retention Payments to the respective Qualifying Key
         Employees.



                                       2





<PAGE>

                           c. All Key Employee Retention Payments with respect
         to retention awards made on or after March 31, 2006 shall be made not
         later than the first business day following the Earned Date.

                  5. PAYMENT CONDITIONED ON EXECUTION OF MERGER AGREEMENT.

                           a. Key Employee Retention Payments shall be made if
and only if the Merger Agreement is executed by authorized representatives of
Exelon Corporation and Enterprise. In the event that the Merger Agreement is
not executed, the Program shall be null and void ab initio, all payments
authorized by the Committee under the Program shall immediately be cancelled,
and no Key Employee shall have any rights or entitlements under the Program.

                           b. In the event that the Merger Agreement terminates
for any reason, the Program shall immediately terminate, all remaining payments
authorized by the Committee under the Program shall immediately be cancelled,
and no Key Employee shall have any rights or entitlements to further amounts
under the Program.

                  6. TERMINATION OF EMPLOYMENT. A Key Employee who incurs a
termination of employment prior to the first anniversary of the Merger Agreement
Date shall not be entitled to receive a Key Employee Retention Payment. A Key
Employee who incurs a termination of employment prior to the Earned Date shall
not be eligible to receive the portion of the Key Employee Retention Payment
that is paid after such date, provided that any Key Employee whose employment is
involuntarily terminated without Cause as of or prior to the Effective Time
shall be deemed to have remained employed through the Earned Date and shall be
treated as a Qualifying Key Employee for all purposes.

                  7. ADMINISTRATION. The Program shall be administered by the
Committee (or any successor thereto) consistent with the purpose and terms of
the Program. The Committee (and any successor thereto) shall have full power and
authority to interpret the Program, to select the employees eligible to
participate, to determine the amount of Key Employee Retention Payments, and to
make any other determinations and to take such other actions as it deems
necessary or advisable in carrying out its duties under the Program, including
the delegation of such authority or power, where appropriate. All decisions and
determinations by the Committee (or any successor thereto) shall be final,
conclusive and binding on Enterprise, Exelon Corporation, all employees and any
other persons having or claiming an interest hereunder.

                  8. AMENDMENT AND TERMINATION.

                           a. The Program may be amended by the Committee at any
time; provided that no amendment shall cause any Key Employee not to be covered
under the Program, reduce the amount of any Key Employee Retention Payment, or
in any other manner adversely affect the rights of any Key Employee to a Key
Employee Retention Payment. Notwithstanding the foregoing, if the Key Employee
Retention Payments are deemed to be "deferred compensation" subject to Section
409A of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended, the




                                       3





<PAGE>

Program shall be deemed to be amended as necessary to conform such payments to
the requirements of Section 409A.

                           b. The Key Employee Retention Program shall terminate
when the total amount of all Key Employee Retention Payments have been paid to
the respective Key Employees or their beneficiaries.

                  9.       MISCELLANEOUS.

                           a. Benefits provided under the Program shall be in
         addition to any increased payments or accelerated vesting available
         under any other employee benefit plan, program or arrangement,
         including an individual employment agreement.

                           b. No Key Employee Retention Payment shall be taken
         into consideration for the calculation of any pension, severance or
         other benefit under any employee benefit plan, program or arrangement.

                           c. The right of a Key Employee to receive a Key
         Employee Retention Payment shall not be deemed a right to continued
         employment prior to, on or after the Effective Time or the Earned Date,
         and shall not entitle the Key Employee to additional retention payments
         under any other retention program implemented by Enterprise or Exelon
         Corporation.

                           d. No person shall have the power or right to
         transfer (other than by will or the laws of descent and distribution),
         alienate or otherwise encumber such person's interest under the Key
         Employee Retention Program. The provisions of the Program shall inure
         to the benefit of each Key Employee and the Key Employee's
         beneficiaries, heirs, executors, administrators and successors in
         interest.

                           e. Enterprise and Exelon Corporation may make such
         provisions and take such action as they may deem necessary or
         appropriate for the withholding of any taxes that Enterprise or Exelon
         Corporation believe to be required by any law or regulation of any
         governmental authority, whether Federal, state or local, to withhold in
         connection with any Key Employee Retention Payment.

                           f. Key Employee Retention Payments shall not, in the
         aggregate, exceed $15,000,000. The cost of the first installment of Key
         Employee Retention Payments shall be borne by Enterprise. All remaining
         costs and expenses of the program shall be borne by Exelon Corporation.

                           g. Following the Effective Time, the Program shall be
         binding on Exelon Corporation to the same extent as if Exelon
         Corporation had expressly assumed the Program.

                           k. The Program and all determinations made and
         actions taken under the Program shall be governed by the laws of New
         York (excluding the choice of law provisions thereof).




                                       4





<PAGE>

                           l. If any provision of the Program is held unlawful
         or otherwise invalid or unenforceable, in whole or in part, the
         unlawfulness, invalidity or unenforceability shall not affect any other
         parts of the Program, which parts shall remain in full force and
         effect.







                                       5




</TEXT>
</DOCUMENT>

                  PUBLIC SERVICE ENTERPRISE GROUP INCORPORATED
               COMPUTATION OF RATIOS OF EARNINGS TO FIXED CHARGES

<TABLE>
<CAPTION>
                                                    For the Three
                                                     Months Ended         For the Years Ended
                                                       March 31,               December 31,
                                                    -------------------------------------------------------
                                                      2006  2005    2005    2004    2003     2002     2001
                                                    -------------------------------------------------------
                                                                  (Millions, except ratios)
<S>                                                  <C>           <C>     <C>     <C>       <C>     <C>
Earnings as Defined in Regulation S-K (A):

Pre-tax Income from Continuing Operations             $342  $451   $1,399  $1,237  $1,324     $659   $1,139
(Income) Loss from Equity Investees, net of
Distributions                                          (23)    1      (28)     78      60       (2)     (59)
Fixed Charges                                          228   232      931     928     963      946      876
Capitalized Interest (B)                               (21)  (26)     (92)   (109)   (116)    (104)     (74)
Preferred Securities Dividend Requirements of
Subsidiaries                                            (2)   (2)      (6)     (6)     (6)      (6)      (8)
                                                    -------------------------------------------------------
Total Earnings                                        $524  $656   $2,204  $2,128  $2,225   $1,493   $1,874
                                                    =======================================================

Fixed Charges as Defined in Regulation S-K (C)

Interest Expense                                      $223  $227     $915    $913    $949     $926     $852
Interest Factor in Rentals                               3     3       10       9       8       14       16
Preferred Securities Dividend Requirements of
Subsidiaries                                             2     2        6       6       6        6        8
                                                    -------------------------------------------------------
Total Fixed Charges                                   $228  $232     $931    $928    $963     $946     $876
                                                    =======================================================

Ratio of Earnings to Fixed Charges                    2.30  2.83     2.37    2.29    2.31     1.58     2.14
                                                    =======================================================
</TABLE>


(A)   The term "earnings" shall be defined as pre-tax Income from Continuing
      Operations before income or loss from equity investees plus distributed
      income from equity investees. Add to pre-tax income the amount of fixed
      charges adjusted to exclude (a) the amount of any interest capitalized
      during the period and (b) the actual amount of any preferred securities
      dividend requirements of majority-owned subsidiaries stated on a pre-tax
      level.

(B)   Fixed Charges represent (a) interest, whether expensed or capitalized, (b)
      amortization of debt discount, premium and expense, (c) an estimate of
      interest implicit in rentals and (d) preferred securities dividend
      requirements of majority-owned subsidiaries stated on a pre-tax level.

(C)   Capitalized Interest excludes AFUDC for PSE&G.




</TEXT>
</DOCUMENT>

                                                                    EXHIBIT 12.1


                     PUBLIC SERVICE ELECTRIC AND GAS COMPANY
               COMPUTATION OF RATIOS OF EARNINGS TO FIXED CHARGES

<TABLE>
<CAPTION>

                                                  For the Three
                                                   Months Ended         For the Years Ended
                                                    March 31,               December 31,
                                                  ------------------------------------------------------
                                                  2006   2005    2005   2004    2003     2002    2001
                                                  ------------------------------------------------------
                                                                (Millions, except ratios)
<S>                                               <C>    <C>     <C>    <C>     <C>      <C>     <C>
Earnings as Defined in Regulation S-K (A):

Pre-tax Income from Continuing Operations          $143  $204    $583   $592    $376     $320    $324
Fixed Charges                                        85    84     342    362     390      408     461
                                                  ------------------------------------------------------
Earnings                                           $228  $288    $925   $954    $766     $728    $785
                                                  ======================================================

Fixed Charges as Defined in Regulation S-K (B)


Interest Expense                                    $85   $84    $342   $362    $390     $406    $458
Interest Factor in Rentals                           --    --      --     --      --        2       3
                                                  ------------------------------------------------------
Total Fixed Charges                                 $85   $84    $342   $362    $390     $408    $461
                                                  ======================================================

Ratio of Earnings to Fixed Charges                 2.68  3.43    2.70   2.64    1.96     1.78    1.70
                                                  ======================================================
</TABLE>


(A)   The term "earnings" shall be defined as pretax income from continuing
      operations. Add to pretax income the amount of fixed charges adjusted to
      exclude the amount of any interest capitalized during the period.

(B)   Fixed Charges represent (a) interest, whether expensed or capitalized, (b)
      amortization of debt discount, premium and expense and (c) an estimate of
      interest implicit in rentals.




</TEXT>
</DOCUMENT>
